The sorrow of war inside a soldier’s heart was in a strange way similar to the sorrow of love. It was a kind of nostalgia, like the immense sadness of a world at dusk. It was a sadness, a missing, a pain which could send one soaring back into the past. The sorrow of the battlefield could not normally be pinpointed to one particular event, or even one person. If you focused on any one event it would soon become a tearing pain.

The next book in my project to read all the past winners of the Independent Foreign Fiction Prize (now the Man Booker International) takes me to 1994 and The Sorrow of War.

It won from a shortlist of; The Following Story by Cees Nooteboom, translated by Ina Rilke; Fima by Amos Oz, translated by Nicholas de Lange; The Moment Between the Past and the Future, by Grigorij Baklanov, translated by Catherine Porter; The Road to San Giovanni by Italo Calvino, translated by Tim Parks and The Infinite Plan by Isabel Allende, translated by Margaret Sayers Peden.

Bảo Nin's Vietnamese original Thân phận của tình yêu (English: The Destiny of Love) was circulated in mimeographed form. Phan Thanh Hao translated it into English and brought it to the attention of a London publisher, who then commissioned journalist and translator Frank Patmos to prepare this final English version.

The judges citation stated (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk... "The Sorrow of War is both remarkable and historic. Usually, history is the story told by the winners; Bao Ninh's book reminds us that, in war, everybody loses."

The novel tells the story of Kien, who fights throughout the Vietnamese war, on the ultimate victorious North Vietnamese side. But as the title suggests, this is certainly not a novel that glorifies war, nor is it one that tries to tell the story of the wider conflict, focusing on the personal impact on the soldiers who fought:

I’m nearly forty. I was eighteen at the start of the war in 1965, twenty-eight at the fall of Saigon in 1975. So, how many long years have passed? Ten or eleven? Twelve. No. Thirteen? Another year with the MIA team. Or was it longer? And more time wandering as a Veteran. Closer to fourteen years lost because of the war.

The author himself fought through the Vietnam War, although he was older at 27 when called up in 1969. Kien's younger age enables the book to more effectively show the stripping away of his innocence, he and his 17 year-old girlfriend Phuong virgins as the conflict begins. This loss of innocence takes place rapidly, in the first few days before he has even reached the front (although the story is only told late in the novel):

We were born pure and innocent. Look how innocent we are now,’ she mumbled. He could hardly miss the allusion to their new status as multiple rape victim and brutal murderer.

Kien is a survivor, ultimately the only one of his brigade to do so, reflecting the author's own experience as one of only 10 out of 500 of his brigade to make it through the war.

At the front, among the dead and surrounded by suffering, he often dreamed of and really felt her warm flesh again and tasted her virgin milk; in his dreams it was that which had given him the magical vitality to become the strongest, the luckiest, the greatest survivor of the war.

The literary strength of the novel comes from the way it is told. This is far from a linear account. It opens with Kien retrieving bodies after the conflict has ended:

on the banks of the Ya Crong Poco River, on the northern flank of the B3 battlefield in the Central Highlands, the Missing In Action body-collecting team awaits the dry season of 1976.

By 40 Kien is a "famous author" but one who is now trying, for cathartic as much as literary purposes, to write the story of his war. The account he writes refuses to follow a simple linear structure, circling back and forth through time:

When starting this novel, the first in his life, he planned a post-war plot. He started by writing about the MIA Remains-Gathering team, those about-to-be-demobilised soldiers on the verge of returning to ordinary civilian life. But relentlessly, his pen disobeyed him. Each page revived one story of death after another and gradually the stories swirled back deep into the primitive jungles of war, quietly re-stoking his horrible furnace of war memories.
...
The memory that afternoon reawakened in him the sense of sacred duty. He felt he must press on to fulfil his obligations, his duty as a writer. It was necessary to write about the war, to touch readers’ hearts, to move them with words of love and sorrow, to bring to life the electric moments, to let them, in the reading and the telling, feel they were there, in the past, with the author. Why choose war? Why must he write of the war? His life and that of so many others was so horrible it could hardly be called a life. How can one find artistic recognition in that kind of life?
...
He dares not abandon himself to emotions, yet in each chapter Kien writes of the war in a deeply personal way, as though it had been his very own war. And so on and on, frantically writing, Kien refights all his battles, relives the times where his life was bitter, lonely, surreal, and full of obstacles and horrendous mistakes. There is a force at work in him that he cannot resist, as though it opposes every orthodox attitude taught him and it is now his task to expose the realities of war and to tear aside conventional images. It is a dangerous spin he is in, flying off at a tangent, away from the traditional descriptive writing styles, where everything is orderly. Kien’s heroes are not the usual predictable, stiff figures but real people whose lives take diverse and unexpected directions.

In the novel we are reading, this is given an added (and perhaps unnecessary) metafictional touch in that in part we are reading Kien's account and in part commentary on it by someone who found the pages, themselves jumbled, and is trying to reassemble the story:

At first I tried to rearrange the manuscript pages into chronological order, to make the manuscript read like the sort of book I was familiar with. But it was useless. There was no chronological order at all. Any page seemed like the first, any page could have been the last. Even if the manuscript had been numbered, even if no pages had been burned, or moth-eaten, or withheld by the author, if by chance they were all there, this novel would still be a work created by turbulent, even manic inspirations.

Although much of Kien's tale is of the brutal reality of war, the futility and the suffering, he does bring out the heroism of others who sacrificed themselves - although he sees these sacrifices as personal, to save their friends, rather than in the furtherance of the cause of those who commissioned the conflict:

But for Hoa and countless other loved comrades, nameless ordinary soldiers, those who sacrificed for others and for their Vietnam, raising the name of Vietnam high and proud, creating a spiritual beauty in the horrors of conflict, the war would have been another brutal, sadistic exercise.

To win, martyrs had sacrificed their lives in order that others might survive. Not a new phenomenon, true. But for those still living to know that the kindest, most worthy people have all fallen away, or even been tortured, humiliated before being killed, or buried and wiped away by the machinery of war, then this beautiful landscape of calm and peace is an appalling paradox. Justice may have won, but cruelty, death and inhuman violence had also won.

And at a personal level, the impact of the conflict is shown on the relationship between Kien and Phuong, each so changed by the war that when they come together again they are essentially different people: Kien says he has only had two loves in his life: Phuong at seventeen in the pre-war days, and Phuong now, after the war but in practice, the changes to each are too much to enable their relationship to survive.

At a purely personal level this didn't quite work for me. Part of the fame the book has achieved has come in Vietnam from the honesty of an account that doesn't present the war as an triumphant heroic victory, and in the US from people being able to read an account from the other side, and see that much of their experience was shared. It must be said to me as a UK reader, where the Vietnamese war was much less of a epoch-defining event, these aspects were rather less powerful. And as mentioned, the meta-fictional aspects of the novel felt a little overdone, even though I normally like this sort of approach in a novel.

Nevertheless a worthwhile winner of a wonderful literary prize. 3.5 stars (less)
An unconventional, powerful novel about the Vietnam war.

A short book about the horrors of war. It appealed because I wanted to read something from the Vietnamese viewpoint.

The protagonist is a survivor - most of his comrades so not make it through the war, and his life after the war is profoundly affected.

The book builds to a horrific event early on in its chronology, which is really sickening but goes a long way to explaining the nihilistic world view of some of the characters. Well worth a read.

At the end of the text, the author writes, “Many would say this was a disruption of the plot, a disconnection, a loss of perspective. They’d say this style proved the writer’s inherent weakness: his spirit was willing but his flesh wasn’t.” (Ninh 230) The novel reads like memories scattered on pages; like diary pages ripped out, shuffled, and sewn together into a story. It has been said that art is either revolution or plagiarism. Bao Ninh certainly takes risk with his writing style, eliminating the classical features of rising action, climax, and so forth. With that being said, this novel is one that Ninh writes for himself, not for the reader. As for the glorified feature of the Northern perspective, there isn’t anything truly fresh about this. Perhaps for some Americans who think that the North Vietnamese are evil , slimy, communists, this book would truly be enlightening, but for most the revelation that North Vietnamese communists are human too will seem rather obvious. But this is more of a grievance with some reviews, and not with the author or the novel. I’m still torn with this novel; so much of my opinion depends upon whether certain elements were intentional or flaws in writing. Throughout the entirety of the novel, Ninh creates a generally nostalgic tone. Sometimes it is to the point of despair, sometimes mere malaise. It is rather overwhelming to be bombarded with the same mood throughout the entire novel. Perhaps Ninh did this intentionally to portray the reality of the world seen through the eyes of Kien. But I find it to be limiting of the storytelling. Another element I found to be distracting was Ninh’s use of the supernatural. Ninh includes ghosts, spirits, and screaming jungles to comment on the dead, but they have a limited effect. I’m sure another author may have been able to use these elements efficiently, but Ninh’s use is rather distracting to the story and flow of time (or lack thereof). In fact, I observed that Ninh ever rarely captivated me with his language. I discussed with a friend that writers like Annie Dillard can make looking out the window as a child seem utterly profound, while Bao Ninh seems to have difficulty making even the most significant of circumstances important. But to Ninh’s credit, I found one description of Kien and Phuong’s love rather amusing: “[Kien’s:] loneliness pierced [Phuong:] like a knife, throbbing painfully.” (Ninh 115) But other than that, I was less than awed. Perhaps, it was the translation. Works in Spanish, for example, are relatively easy to translate into English, but other languages may not be so. Russian, in particular, is difficult. Perhaps, some of the novel’s power is lost in the translation. There are a few beautiful pieces of prose within The Sorrow of War, but they are limited to a few passages. I felt the ending was stronger than the rest of the novel. In fact, it could have been much better if it had been shortened. The way it stands now is just too long for what it says. I really wanted to fall in love with this book, but the writing style made it impossible for me. If you’re looking for a good Vietnam novel, read The Things They Carried by Tim O’Brien. Strangely enough, they both novels are set up in vignette styled stories, but O’Brien has the talent to pull it off. Do I recommend this novel? Not over many others. But it has some redeemable qualities and some readers, I’m sure, will find his writing style to suit them. (less)

I had always felt guilty that I had not read such an important work of fiction about the Vietnam War. So when I was at Tan Son Nhat airport looking for some reading materials to buy before I boarded the plane back to Singapore, I asked the shop attendant:
- Chị ơi có cuốn "Nỗi buồn chiến tranh" không chị? (Hello, do you have the book "The sorrow of war"?)
Then she replied:
- Dạ hông có chị ơi em xin lỗi (We don't have that book, I am sorry).
I was very surprised to hear that, because I knew that this book was very popular outside Vietnam and whenever I saw some book lists about Vietnam, the name of this book would appear. So I took a look around the shelf, and I found the book in English. So I told the lady:
- Ủa chị ơi nó đây nè! (But hey, here it is!)
And the lady said:
- Ủa vậy sao chị không hỏi em có cuốn "The sorrow of war" hay không. Em đâu có biết "The sorrow of war" là "Nỗi buồn chiến tranh đâu". Nói "The sorrow of war" là em biết liền à! (Oh why didn't you ask me [the title of the book in English]? I had no idea that [the book's English title] is [the book's Vietnamese title]. If you had asked me in English, I would have known].

It's just funny how people outside Vietnam read some book about Vietnam, consider it to be so important. And yet Vietnamese people like me and that lady have not even read the book at all, or cannot even form a link between the book's English title and Vietnamese title.

So I bought the book in English for 14 US dollars and boarded the plane. I read about 40+ pages and suddenly, tears rolled down my face. It was not that the book was excellent, it was more about me feeling sad that when people look at Vietnam, most of the time they would just remember about the Vietnam War; and that the people in Vietnam had gone through so many things in the war and yet 40 years later, their sufferings still felt so real just like yesterday.

When I reached Singapore, I went online to continue reading the book in Vietnamese. And wow, what an experience. The book felt totally different. The English translation made me feel like listening to a story from a person who I don't know, and because of that, I wanted to know more although the book was not very well-written. The Vietnamese version, on the other hand - and I am gonna be honest here, was very cliche with its choice of words and writing to the point of being boring that I had to skim a number of pages, although I was sure I understood the Vietnamese version much better. I believe this had to do with the book's narrative which was mostly flashbacks, the characterisation which was not very in-depth - probably because I felt that the author wrote this for himself, rather than for someone else to read, you know what I mean?

It's nice to get to see someone's honest point of view about a topic that was overanalysed and I truly appreciated Mr Bảo Ninh's efforts, but that does not necessarily make an excellent work of fiction. (less)

"The novel was the ash from this exorcism of devils."

At all turns a tremendous and ghastly novel of war and most especially its aftermath. This might very well be the best "war" novel I've ever read, though it is far more about piecing together one's experience in war and trying to sift through it for a sign of how one should go on.
Kien is the thinly-disguised author who, I'm assuming, drew off his own horrific experience over the decade of the Vietnam War, as a soldier from the North. Kien remembers terrifying and often gory goings-on on the battlefield while struggling to cope with peace, all the while wondering if it was worth it. In a telling touch, Kien is also a novelist.
Naturally, it is nice to get the North Vietnamese perspective, which had little to do with ideology (barely mentioned here) and more about simply fighting for your freedom. American readers familiar with the Vietnam War industry in art, will be surprised at how similar the experiences were.
But more than all that war shit, this is a tremendous novel because it is at all times touching and moving amidst all the horror, with smatterings of loves found and lost, surreal moments of charity on the battlefield, and poetic instances where they don't belong. (less)

As a soldier who did a 14 month tour in Vietnam and 14 plus years active duty, I hardly know where to begin the review this book. I graduated from high school in 1965, joining the Army a year later. This is the story of Bao Kien, a North Vietnamese soldier and my enemy. When he was 17, in 1965, just graduated rom high school in Hanoi, he was conscripted to the Glorius 27th Youth Brigade in the North Vietnamese Army. The author writes transparently, making it difficult to tell which is fiction and which is auto-biography.

In writing this apparent memoir, Bao writes that "writing is the last effort of a soldier, to tell the story of war." For Bao, each page, written over a period of nearly 20 years after the end of the war, revived one story of death after another. Bao writes to rid himself of his devils. After eleven years of service, when the ARVN were defeated on April 30, 1975, in his advanced scout Platoon, he was the sole survivor.

Where my tour was pre-determined, a finite 13 months, Kien's was date uncertain, infinite. How long, he ponders? Five years? 10? 20? The duration? His tour was filled with jungles, swamps, mud and leeches, just like mine. Coming from a culture of superstitions, his was filled with ghosts, spirits, incense, smoke, bullets, bombs and uncertainty, the only certainty, in his eyes and experience, being death. The period 1968-69 was his worst nightmare. Of the 500 men in his Battalion 27 who went to battle against the Americans in the Central Highlands, during the dry season of 1969, Kien was one of only ten who survived the battle. Coincidentally, the same period was the worst for American casualties.

Whomp! Whomp! Whomp! A comforting sound to every GI. Here comes the cavalry! Hot food, water, mail, more ammo, reinforcements, dust off for wounded, a ride home. For Kien, the sound of dread: bullets, rockets and certain death, second only to the relentless artillery and air barrage.

Unlike many American-written books and movies that emphasize the blood, guts and glory of war, Bao only relates a few battles and personally poignant deaths, he preferring to emphasize the overall trauma of war. In his words, "Losses can be made good, damage can be repaired and wounds will heal in time, but the psychological scars of the war will remain forever." "The spirits of all those killed in the war will remain beyond all political consequences of the war," writes Bao, as he questions the "why" of the war. He describes the fall of Saigon on April 30, not as a joyous victory and a celebration of the end of the war, but a surreal apocalypse as soldiers became madmen, killing wantonly and looting for souvenirs. There was no glory, no trumpets for their victorious soldiers returning home. Returning to Hanoi on the troop train, Kien found no fanfair, no utopian dream of gloriously returning to Phoung, his childhood sweetheart. Over eleven years of war, they had both changed, drifted apart and there was a new "Jody" in the picture. After the war, Kien only found emptiness and utter isolation. War was all he knew, there being no job for which him to return. Trying to escape his ghosts, devils and nightmares, there is nowhere for him to turn, his friends all killed in the war, his family all gone. He turns to alcohol and, ultimately, to his writing. He struggles with the lack of a future and prefers to live in the past, in spite of the pain found there, the never-ending past, Bao's story of loyalty, friendship, brotherhood, comradeship and humanity.

I have met mine enemy . . . and he is us. Bao, thank you for writing your story. My salute and my respect. (less)

A rare insight into the mind of a North Vietnam soldier. He seemed driven by a duty to be a good soldier, a mate but realistic that they were fighting a more well equipped enemy so life was likely to be short. There was no ideology driven mantra. His experiences in the war were brutal and after the war he struggles with his experiences, of lives lost and finding a future. Interesting that the returned soldiers received the same disinterested reception as their American and allies received.
The book is a bit of a disjointed set of memories, jumping between per-War, War, post-War scenes and Kien's relationship with Phuong. Kien's world lacks emotion and feelings. Women suffer more as the men have been trained to be violent, be emotionless and rape is a result of that doctrine.
It's a haunting book. (less)
heartbreaking and deep

Kien became a writer to try to piece his life together, though, he continued to experience "...similar, even identical moments, long periods of withdrawal. Like the dead, one felt no fear, no enthusiasm, no joy, no sadness, no feelings for anything. No concerns and no hopes. One was totally devoid of feeling and had no regard for the clever or the stupid, the brave or the cowardly, commanders r privates, friend or foe, life or death, happiness or sadness. It was all the same; it amounted to nothing."

He writes because he must...and what he writes is this book.

War changes everything: the way one thinks, the way one remembers, who one is, who others are, who one was, who they were, how it was, how it is...and then there are the ghosts, not only of comrades and friends, but those who would have been what if their lives had not been changed by war.

Kien was a soldier. Then, he worked to retrieve bodies and have them identified so that their families could re-bury them with their ancestors. Then, he searched for himself and for the world, now so very different from what it had once been, now a world where ghosts hold his being in their hands, in their cries.

This is a brilliant and beautiful book about humanity and the power of the narratives that explode in people's minds. Not to be missed.
(less)

A searing, sorrowful book about the Vietnam War, written by a North Vietnamese veteran who weathered the deadliest, most turbulent years of the conflict. The vignettes that comprise much of this work seem to be deeply informed by Ninh’s own experiences as a young soldier, to the point that the narrative perspective occasionally slips from the fictional third person to the more visceral first. This is a fevered, elliptical account in which truth and fiction, past and present, memory and nostalgia bleed and blur together, leaving the impression of national and personal traumas that have no real beginning and no real end. Reading this novel feels like carrying a body across 233 pages—by no means a light or easy journey, and one that offers little in the way of relief. (less)

On March 6, 2018 I read a short piece in "Counterpunch" by Marc Levy entitled "William Joiner Institute Under Siege."
Two days later after finishing a book, I was going through a pile of books to read and found this book, and thought I just read a mention of this book. I went back to "Counterpunch" and re-read Levy. In his piece, he describes reading the book and floating above his bed. This was the Universe directing me to read this.

Thank you Universe.

"The Sorrow of War" is about so much: the Vietnam War which has shaped much of my life, about the personal destruction of wars, and also about writing, love, and memory. (less)

A book written about the Vietnam war from the perspective of a North Vietnamese solider. The story is about a soldier who has flashbacks to the war and to cure his demons he writes down the memories of his traumatic experiences. The book is brutal in the futility and arbitrariness of fate. He is one of a few survivors from his battalion.

The innocence of his childhood and the insanity of the war is wonderfully described. A novella well worth reading and I can understand why it won the independent foreign fiction award. (less)

War is not fun. For a detailed account of just how complicatedly unfun war gets, read this book. It is not fun, the title says as much, but life gets that way for a lot of unfortunate people who are just born on the wrong side of a shitstorm, and very few get to survive and even tell the tale in a sublimely meaningful way.
Bao Ninh's book is a sensitive, unflinching and relentless venture, coming to terms with what most readers will hopefully not recognize as their own life. This is a strenuous read, well-translated into English by Phan Thanh Hao, and nothing like any other war books I've read - although in many ways reminiscent of many real-life survivor accounts. A markedly romantic approach to narration is counterpointed with meticulous composition and unquestionable authenticity. A highly respectable work, worthy of international attention. (less)

A friend of mine gave me a copy of this book that he had brought back from a trip to Costa Rica in the mid-1990s. It haunts me still when I reflect upon it and burns in my subconscious like the Wille Pete (white phosphorous) our military used to terrorize the Vietnamese. It is the story of Kien, a North Vietnamese soldier. After the war, in 1976, Kien and others are sent to the Central Highlands to collect bodies for reburial. They are sent to The Jungle of Screaming Souls where Kien was the only survivor of his battalion. Kien’s tale reveals hard truths known to every common soldier in every war in history: “What remained was sorrow, the immense sorrow, the sorrow of having survived. The sorrow of war.” The psychological damage to the young men who fought in these wars, are the wounds that never heal. The Sorrow of War won the Independent Foreign Fiction Prize in 1994. (less)

This is one of the best books I've ever read (and yes, I know, I say that a lot).

I am shocked by reviews from readers being "Vietnamed out" when they read this. I mean, it's from the perspective of an NVA soldier. Maybe we should all read more books by North Vietnamese authors. It's not like it glorified the war or demonized Americans and the ARVN. It was completely refreshing to me.

When I started this book, I had just read a book from the American perspective of the Vietnam War. Some of the American soldiers, of course, had no idea what the hell they were doing there and wanted out. The same was true for so many NVA soldiers. I mean, we know this, that the NVA were human beings. But it just feels so good to read about NVA soldiers busy being human. It feels good to see that as idiotic as the war was, we all have the same worries and wants.

Some things that stuck with me:

1. There is a part of this book where Kien sees an American patrol and he is absolutely terrified. From his point of view, the Americans are as "other" as he is to them.

2. As awful as we like to imagine war is, our perception is nowhere as awful as it is for someone like Kien (and most veterans for that matter). Coronavirus doesn't even come close to eleven years of military service in a civil war.

3. The ARVN are much more present in this book than in most America-centric Vietnam War books, which was also enlivened my reading experience. This and the fact that many NVA troops could not have cared less about their government's ideology, including the ones who volunteered. (This is partly why Bảo Ninh has been quite unpopular with the Vietnamese government.)

4. The NVA troops weren't all brainwashed communists or something. They weren't blind and deaf. They knew what their government was doing.

5. There are so many good people out there, and also so many people who would turn to animals and destroy your life the first chance they got. War has a way of warping you even when you have good intentions. For example, in one part of the book, Kien gets upset at his guide, who is quite young, because she accidentally gets his platoon lost.

6. There is a part of the book where Kien considers deserting to be with his sort-of girlfriend. However, he knows he will be shot as a deserter if he doesn't report to his - okay never mind. I don't know. I don't even know what I'm writing right now. I was going to just copy paste all the notes I took, but it would all be out of context. Basically this book is one giant nightmare in book form. It is about one more person's experience with war and hardship.

Which is exactly why you should read it.

"‘So, you’re off to the war? Not that I can prevent you. I’m old, you are young. I couldn’t stop you if I wanted to. I just want you to understand me when I say that a human being’s duty on this earth is to live, not to kill,’ he said. ‘Taste all manner of life. Try everything. Be curious and inquire for yourself. Don’t turn your back on life.’" (less)

as fascinating as this novel is, i can't help feeling a bit disappointed with it now that i'm finished. to my western eyes, it's pretty unique - a diaristic, plot-less account of a north vietnamese soldier's hardships during a war i'm well-versed in seeing from the opposite perspective. i'm a bit ashamed to admit this, but i don't think i've ever read a vietnamese novel before, so the fact that a few areas didn't resonate with me may reflect my own ignorance about the culture the novel comes from.

the protagonist (kien) spends the majority of the book fluctuating between shell-shocked depression and bitter nostalgia. time shifts rapidly in the book, and i enjoyed the challenge of keeping up with the shifts. structurally, this deepens the individual memories and adds considerable weight to the book's conclusion.

on the other hand, there's an ever-present dichotomy between purity and impurity that i found to be a big limitation. kien isn't so much a character as a vessel for the novel's bleak worldview and cynicism about war and political conflict. he longs for an idealized past that the novel too often takes for granted - particularly during the encounters with his childhood sweetheart phoung, who also seems to be more of a symbol than a person. at times, this works well - especially when counter-balanced by the more draconian elements of communist orthodoxy (i.e. the "three don'ts," which forbid young people from the pleasures of sex, love and marriage). but the rigid binaries between peace and conflict become repetitive and affect-less at times. some of the novel's darker passages begin to seem inevitable, and (at times) lose a bit of their impact as the narrative progresses. (less)

This is a powerful novel about the war in Viet Nam written by a soldier from North Viet Nam. In some ways, it resonates with the powerful novels about the war written by American GIs -- traumatic flashbacks, PTSD, desperate solutions through alcohol and rage -- but, of course, it is profoundly different because the war takes place in his homeland and affects his family, his lover, the land and everyone around him so deeply. The main character, Kien, is also writing a novel about his war experience -- or maybe not a novel, maybe just jumbled memories, non-chronological battle scenes, jottings about childhood -- in a bleak room in a shambling, almost-empty apartment building in Hanoi after the war. There are no chapters because the random papers, abandoned and blown about in a storm, are pieced together by the woman upstairs who finds them. Characters appear and reappear, even after we know they have been killed in battle as most of Kien't comrades were. Most memorable is his childhood love Phuong, whom he loses when the Americans bomb the freight train they are riding. When he finds her again, it turns out that -- though they are both alive -- neither of them have survived in tact. Beautifully written, definitely sorrowful.
(less)

When I read Anthony Bourdrain’s A Cook’s Tour, he mentioned that he got a copy of Bao Nihn’s war novel, The Sorrow of War, and consumed it in an afternoon at the beach while visiting Vietnam. So I decided to see what it was about. It’s a short, but powerful novel that illustrates the destructive nature of war. It’s not always the battle itself, but the situations people find themselves in because of the war. The loss of innocence, unruly behavior of humans in general, the break up of families and lovers. There were two brutal violations of women that took place in the novel that I had difficulty in forgetting. The structure is somewhat disjointed as several different stories converge and an underlying tone of sadness and suffering permeates throughout. It is a war classic since it stays with you like all the great war novels: ie Going After Cacciato, or All Quiet on The Western Front. (less)

I was lucky enough to find a special English copy full of marginalia at a second hand book stall on Nguyen Van Binh in Ho Chi Minh City (or Saigon).

A Vietnamese person had been reading it and every space is filled with their handwriting in ink or pencil where they translated words and phrases.

I found the story to be very powerful and tragic, showing how Kien and Phuong’s lives were stolen by the war even though they survived it.

I think it would have been beautiful if it ended on page 209 with the line: “…echoing somehow through the darkness.”

I was surprised to see the author in Ken Burns's Vietnam documentary series; a great program for anyone who wants to learn more about the war.
(less)

While traveling in Vietnam, I was informed that the Vietnamese refer to 'the Vietnam War' as 'the American War.' I think it's easy to lose track of the fact that there are two sides to every conflict. Without getting into the politics of whether war is ever justified, this book is a reminder of the damage done to the ordinary people who get caught up in it. But Ninh's book is a whole lot more than a cautionary tale about the effects of war. It's a dreamy, poetic recounting of youth and love and loss - where the harsh reality of what he describes blurs in a vaporous world of jungles and superstition. (less)

FINALLY finished this book! It started out really great but it grew increasingly confusing and boring and also I read this for school and I have a teacher who expects extremely thorough annotations so it was basically a torture to go through this book because I had to force myself to slave through it and jot down seemingly meaningful notes in the small margins and it quite possibly took me more than 24 hours straight to annotate the entire book because I remember slaving away for 4 hours each on two plane rides and only getting about a 100 pages done. LOL! IB HL ENGLISH IS A WONDERFUL COURSE! IT FUELS MY LOVE FOR LITERATURE!!! (less)

Fascinating, insightful, touching, poignant, tragic and sad. This novel is Vietnam's answer to All Quiet on the Western Front, being highly descriptive of a war in which the author participated.

What makes it far more interesting is that he was in the North Vietnamese Army, the book offering a very different viewpoint to all the other books about the Vietnam conflict I have read.

It proves (yet again) that whatever the rights and wrongs of the politics, when countries go to war, ordinary people suffer.

It took me a while to get into the story because it was written in a different style to what I am used to but once I got into it I enjoyed it all the more.

Highly recommended. (less)

In beautiful writing this books examins the inability to cope with the horrors of war. I wasn't always the biggest fan of Kien's relationship to Phuong, but it showcased the changes in him so well and how he experiences the time before, during and after serving. The book felt nuanced and was succesful at transporing the feelings. (less)
Waiting for a movie version

I've never been less excited about having to teach a book.
Maybe I've just been lucky thus far.

I read this book specifically for the Works in Translation part of the IB course. Outside of that, I would not choose to read Sorrow of War: I'm not a reader of life writing, because I don't believe that an interesting life necessarily ensures a 'good' story.

I 'get' what the author is doing here, and I 'get' why it's important - Sorrow of War presents the 'other side' to a tale we too frequently dismiss in the West. As an Australian reader, I know that we don't even talk about the Vietnam War from 'our' perspective, because it was such a violent and bloody mistake. So yes, hearing the other side is certainly important for a range of reasons.

But it's not a novel that I enjoyed.

Kien, for all he has seen, is just not an interesting or likeable character. And I could roll with that if war had changed him, but I didn't see much to like in his characterisation before the war either. He's not particularly intelligent, or insightful, or even just interesting, which makes his descent into alcohol fuelled depression seem rather insignificant. Again, I get it - war hurts even the boring people, but as a protagonist, he seems like a weird choice to garner sympathy.

His relationship with Phuong completely did my head in. He was attracted to her because she was a beautiful free spirit, but then seemed to resent that in her at the same time. His instinctual misogyny was reflected in their sexual interactions (view spoiler) Sure, it's all pretty traumatic at that point, but that kind of derogatory reaction to the woman you love is a little off, in my books. It was an attitude which he extended to most of the women in the book - they were whores on the periphery of his tale (though one got close enough to give him VD?) or scorned for their inconsistency (in the case of both Phuong and his mother - some Freudian issues there maybe?)

However, the thing that really prevented me from connecting with the story was the perspective and mode of narration. I'd never realised how much I cherished chapters until I read Sorrow of War. It's intentionally chaotic, jumping from time to time and place to place with no rhyme or reason. Sometimes it would circle back around and retell events with little in the way new information or insight the second time around. And then the kicker came in the final pages when it was revealed that the manuscript had been taken by an intermediary to a publisher who, surprise, surprise, realised he met Kien in the war. The lack of order wasn't intentional after all - the pages had been disrupted and no one could sort out the correct order again. (To be fair, there were a couple of awkward hints at this earlier on, so it wasn't a shocking plot twist.)
It's all a little too reminiscent of Ian McEwan's wanky manipulation of narrator in Atonement (the bit at the end where he reveals that the last half of the book is a lie, because he's an author and he can do that). I was actually on board with the concept of the shifting, twisting narration - it seemed to me like the book's most interesting comment on The Sorrow - that it was ceaseless, unpredictable and shifting...something that affected the rest of someone's life. But no, it was just because the pages fell apart...

I'm willing to chalk some of my qualms up to the fact that it's a translation (the plot scattering aside!). At times, the dialogue felt wooden and overly formal, and the descriptions sometimes didn't sit right - all likely lost in translation. I understand why this novel is IMPORTANT, and I've certainly been given pause to think further about a time and event which I've frequently taught in History classes, but I didn't enjoy the journey. (less)

A personal account of how the American war affected the author (a Vietnamese living in post-war Hanoi). Sad and depressing – the author is trying to come to terms with his life, his choices, his regrets.
There is a lot of lament, woe, and self-pity… When you are in such pain, perhaps all that gives you solace is the bedding of a woman. This distorted perception of life runs in every male character Young ladies be prepared.

It is hard to follow the story because the author jumps around to periods of his life timeline with no seeming order. This is the cultural Sapir-Whorfing of storytelling. His narration of events often confused me and I found myself in a new style of reading whereupon I often had to reimagine the previous events he described to fit new, ongoing details.

But there are moments of beauty in his writing too and to hear a Vietnamese narration of the war is important for Americans.

When I heard Tim O’Brien speak in college I was surprised that he made up some of the stories, these are after all describing war. He explained how it was necessary to write fiction in war novels because the real brutality of war isn't given its full accord when you write with historical accuracy –

But here, the author appears to have made up a number of details – not for any symbolic effect that I can ascertain – just bad storytelling. Is he trying to keep our interest by limiting the number of characters? For example, the 3rd time he saves a woman from being attacked – and it’s his long-lost love Phuong! its clearly unbelievable. Is this some kind of dream-like state where his mind is tortured because he is away from her, or am I reaching for straws trying to justify these storylines.

There are some poignant quips about war, even if some of them are cliche - cliches have a way of being true. Bao describes war behavior as the “brutality that warps soul and personality. The thirst for killing, the cruelty, the animal psychology, the evil desperation.” and “Heroes in war are inconsistent and contradictory, ”

There were a lot more, but due to my poor reading skills I didn't have a pen handy so now I cannot seem to find those passages. Reminds me of the Mitch Hedburg story about how he has to convince himself his jokes aren't funny so he wouldn't have to get out of bed and get a pen to write them down.

Overall, I was disappointed, despite expectations that this wouldn't be written by Ernest Hemingway, the author's narrative style remains unclear and the message of wars misery is a path well trod on at this point. (less)
Sadly, but Nope...

This book really deserves five stars, let me tell you my journey with it... (There may be some little spoilers, sorry, it's hard to write a review without them)

At first, in about the first 50 pages, I mean, the plot seemed all over the place to me and that wasn't pleasant. The author leaped from one battlefield to another, to one postwar experience to a prewar one, which made the plotline very hard to follow. But as the story progressed, and I got more insides about the protagonist, Kien, I found Ninh's style's purpose. Since the war is so chaotic itself, the structure couldn't be clear. He wanted to express those moments, when you are walking in the streets after a war and you are having flashbacks as clear as if they were happening right now. Also, Kien is a writer, thus he is forced to relive those moments on and on in order to give them to the paper.

So this was clear, but why did I like it so much? Well, the first allusion was Gatsby. In The Sorrow of War, Bao Ninh writes, that Kien wanted to follow that "shining light from the horizons of the past" (217). Come on, this is exactly what Gatsby had! The green light that Nick described. And Gatsby had also fought in a war. Maybe that's why both of them were chasing this light... Because during war you need hope, because, as Ninh says, to be "young, very pure and very sincere" (233). That's why Gatsby was chasing this dream. Because as long as he had the vision of the light, nothing could stop him. That's when Gatsby was so great... He believed his war had a purpose. And his life had a purpose as well. It's all a matter of believing.

And this is when my love towards Naruto comes in. For those who don't know, Naruto is a Japanese Anime by Masashi Kishimoto. And those "human bonds" (233) that Ninh talks about are so deeply explored in there. Naruto showed me that who you are is determined by your bonds. Even if there is war, there is a way to be human and pure, it is by having those strong bonds and believing in the purpose of what you are doing.

An amazing beat, if you want to see my observations while reading the book, you may look at my annotations. (less)

Ok, before I start with my impressions of this novel, here’s a copy of some feedback I sent to Random House UK:


The book I received (The Sorrow of War) is not the quality I have come to expect from Vintage (Random House). This edition ISBN 9780749397111 is published under the Minerva imprint, but it looks more like a pirated copy. It has the same cover as the original Vintage edition with the B&W photo of a soldier, except that there are typos in the back page blurbs (“untilnow”, “Pulitze”, “require reading”), and the Vintage logo has been replaced by Minerva.

The verso page looks a lot like a badly done scan of the Vintage verso page, and nowhere on the pages (as distinct from the cover) is Minerva Press mentioned at all. The scanned pages are badly mis-aligned, and some words in the text have letters incompletely printed, making it hard to read.

If this edition has indeed been reprinted by Random House as Print On Demand under the Minerva imprint (See http://www.randomhouse.co.uk/about-us... for the history of their acquisitions) then Random House should be ashamed of themselves.

Ok, got that? Yes, I am very cross indeed that a fine book like this one, should be so shabbily published. I have had Print-on-Demand books before, and while I don’t like the cheap print, they have been readable enough. But this one is a disgrace.

What I didn’t know when I sent that feedback because I hadn’t read very far, was that there’s an even bigger problem: some of the pages are out of order and some of them are missing altogether. I now think it’s possible that this copy is a counterfeit copy, possibly not published by Random House’s Minerva imprint at all…

To read the rest of my disconcerting experience with this book, please visit http://anzlitlovers.com/2015/02/22/th... (less)

After ten years of fighting as a North Vietnamese soldier, protagonist Kien is writing—as is the author, Bao Ninh—to exorcise the war and to comprehend the incomprehensible: life; death. The Sorrow of War is a meditation, a map of memory superimposed over a map of Vietnam.

Kien describes himself as having taken a U-turn after the war. What he sees before him is not the future, but “spreading before him are the past forty years” compelling him “to march forever along the road of the past.”

“Who else but you can experience your life?” These words were spoken to Kien on the eve of war as an encouragement to survive, but they echo throughout the book, because, indeed, no one else can know what we carry around with us. No one can know our past, know what we know, our ghosts, our regrets, the spooling memories—unless we write them down, record them somehow.

“It was by night that the old, true stories began to flow back, bringing their own urgency to him. He needed to trap them as they emerged, to get the details down. Parts of stories he thought he’d forgotten floated through his mind, like disconnected mathematical equations, and he’d grab them and pin them down on paper forever.”

But the writing won’t bend to Kien’s will. Stories come to him in no particular order, memory and war having their own logic or none at all; time is not a factor, sequence is inconsequential. When Kien disappears at the end of the book, the narrator tries to reassemble the random pages, saying, “Any page seemed like the first, any page could have been the last.”

This suddenly appearing narrator could be Kien himself, transformed, redeemed by the writing, by the exorcising of the past. Or he could be Bao Ninh, the author. But any book-within-a-book quality is only incidental, and whatever is murky in this book is rightly so.

The Sorrow of War: politics doesn’t enter into it.
(less)

Oh , wow . A totally new perspective of the Vietnam war . The northern soldiers weren’t just brave and willing to die for “miền Nam phía trước”( the south ahead ) as those taught in school . Of course they were courageous and nationalistic . But there are much more in this book . It featured all kinds of human involved in war and the post-war era : a deserter , an immobilised veteran who lived a plant-like life after war , a prostitute whose brother died battling , an innocent girl whose life ruined by some northern sailors , many soldiers died a tragic death to enemy’s AKs , a woman lived alone after all of her family were killed , 3 young girls who were so young and so in love died by the hand of the southern , and , Kien , the narrator , haunted by comrades’ deaths and lost the love of his life . Everything in this book is ... sorrow . Sorrow during wartime , during peacetime , drunk time , conscious time . The book is a mixed-up between Kien’s present , the pre-war time and his memories of war . It kept flashing back to tragic memories in no order at all , to the day when he was a teenager in Hanoi , in love with Phuong , to the trip they made to the south , to Phuong’s tragedy and then back to present , to Kien’s drunk nights , to Phuong’s new libertine lifestyle . It described how the memories of fallen comrades , the new miserable lives of badly wounded veterans and families of the dead destroyed Kien’s life , made him lose all hope with Phuong now went to bed with strangers regularly and had left him forever . Not only the soldiers suffered . Those who stayed behind suffered too . Not only the wartime is sorrowful . The peacetime is ,too . Not only the enemy had evil or coward soldiers . We had , too . In the battlefield , noone shows mercy , no matter it’s us or the enemy . In the battlefield , everyone is heartless , selfish and indifferent towards deaths . Everyone . (less)

I really wanted to love this book as I needed something from the NVA perspective for my Vietnam Era class.
Positives:
There were parts in which I will have my class read to show them that the story of the NVA could be of any soldier-in the end the human side of war makes us all the same, no matter which side we are on.
It did show the struggle of the NVA-the length of their war, the suffering, the way life was for them upon their return.
The story of this returning soldier and his struggles with PTSD and adjusting back into civilian life could be the story of a soldier from either side.
Negatives:
There were no breaks in the chapters. The story rambled and went back and forth and then returned to earlier events-it was confusing if you didn't sit and read the story all at once. Putting it down and returning to it over time didn't work.
I didn't appreciate the love story with Phoung until the end when he explains what happened on the train that changed her. Up until then her character was not making sense/a connection to me nor was the character of the mute girl.
In the end they portrayed-the abuse of women during war, the lose of love during war, being changed by war, the need to have someone listen to our war stories but not to respond or critize them.
The concluding part about the storyteller trying to put the author's pages together illustrated why the story was written in such a choppy way-but I still didn't like the writing technique.
I can see why the book was banded in Vietnam and this will help foster discussion in my course about how governments want war to be portrayed versus the reality of it.
Love the human emotion, the raw, realitic account of war-hated the style in which it was written. (less)

I am so torn with this one and till now cannot decide on my general emotion and opinion towards it. I genuinely wanted to love this one; I mean yes, I did like it, but I did not love it. As my first delve into War novels, I expected this book to be emotionally shattering and gut wrenching to say the least, but I was met with slight disappointment.

In defense of the author, it is in itself very difficult to describe your own emotions and horror of War, but even more so to portray them in such a way as to actually succeed in attaining empathy from the readers. This is hardly an excuse though, as I have been driven by other authors to tears from their description of horrific incidents or scenes in a more than sublime manner.

Another issue I had with the reading of this book was in its disorienting and non-linear style. In the closing of the book the fictional narrator, who himself had obtained this fictional manuscript from the fictional protagonist, gives explanation to this style of writing as being due to the "author" of the manuscript writing this not with the intention to publish, but merely because of a necessity to jot down his thoughts as a form of self-therapy. Although it was difficult for me to wrap my head around the flashbacks within the flashbacks and the continuous jumping back and forth in time, I nevertheless do understand how this style can be interpreted to be artistic, and as such won't critic it too harshly in this factor.

Honestly, if not for the beautiful yet grizzly plot, the wonderful yet often interrupted flow of this novel and simply the horrific yet brave and telling stories contained within this book, I would have rated it much lower than I have here. All in all, it was a great read. (less)

This is a searing and readable anti-war novel from the perspective of a North Vietnamese soldier. In his depiction of jungle warfare in the 1960s versus a first-world war machine, the terror, trauma, miserable conditions, and grotesque violence (including "a rain of arms and legs" onto the grass by a river following a B-52 raid) is told with a kind of bitter poetry. But the narrative is made even more compelling by a love story that makes war seem that much more insane and sorrowful. The extended scene when Kien, the soldier, flees with his young lover Phuong while jets destroy a train station near Hanoi, is unforgettable. The translation is excellent, too. (less)

How many stories have we seen about the Vietnam war? How many feature the North Vietnamese? This is the first I've seen.

It's fiction but I suspect a great deal is based on the author's experience. He was with the 27th Glorious Youth Brigade, which numbered 500 at the start. He was one of ten who survived.

The protagonist is Kien, a young man who joins the army at the beginning of the war and who survives attack after attack. He sees death almost daily while fighting, and returns home with memories of those who did not make it. In a disjointed way, the way memories take us, the book jolts from one incident to another and back to the present.

Kien falls in love as a teenager and cannot forget Phuong through all the long years, ten long years, and he finds her when he returns. But she is changed just as he is. Ultimately Kien spends most of his time in his little room, writing. Did Bao Ninh do the same? Is that how this novel got written?

The book does not speak from a political position. It is not about North Vietnam so much as it is about war itself, and particularly about such a long, bloody war. It is written simply, with restrained emotion, and is powerful because of that. (less)

When I go to a new country I like to read a novel based in or written in that country. When I went to Vietnam I didn't want to read a Vietnam War book. However I ended up doing so and was not disappointed as this is a brilliant, though harrowing, novel.

Though I shouldn't call it the "Vietnam" war, as it was not confined purely to that country's borders, it was the American War as it is known in that part of the world (a name which could be given to many wars all over the world in the latter half of the 20th and these first two decades of the 21st centuries), so I will call it such.

It is not an orderly. tidy book, it is a mess of flashbacks, jumps forward, tangents and trains of thought. It is shell-shock, it is lying in the back of an army truck bumping through a jungle, it is dying of malaria in a field hospital, it is riding on a train whilst bombs fall all around, it is sleeping next to rotting corpses, it is witnessing the atrocities that man commits against its fellow man, it is the indiscriminate killing of those who have no idea what the ideology in whose name they die even means, it is loss of loved ones, loss of home, loss of self, it is drinking to forget, it is suicidal, it is masochistic, it is sadistic, it is pitiful, it is pitiless, it is a mass of contradictions, rambling thoughts and sober observations. It is a book that many more people should read. (less)

I had to read this book for school and I went through different phases with it.

Phase 1: This Sucks

You cannot read this book in parts. It will feel like a jumble of pointlessness. I only truly got into the book after the first 100 pages and ever after that it wasn't like I couldn't put it down or anything.

Phase 2: I feel like I'm going to cry but no tears come out

This probably has to do most with the point of view. To me, it felt like there was no plot. I couldn't really empathize with the narrator and although I felt sad, it was an uncomfortable sort of sad. Like I was going to throw up any second.

Phase 3: Depression

The climax of this book is that one point when the depression level reaches an all-time high. It's at this point when you realize that there is not going to be a happy ending (in case you haven't already caught on by the title 'Sorrow of War').

Phase 4: Reading it again

When I went back, from the beginning, to read the book again in order to prepare for the test, I actually enjoyed the book. The pieces fit together, and it all made sense. That is, I didn't feel utterly confused and out of place during the first 100 pages, trudging through each paragraph grudgingly. (less)

Bao Ninh struck me as one of the sharpest interviewees in the powerful documentary “Vietnam” by ken burns, with his sorrowful and smart eyes, his soft voice and a constant cigarette smoke hovering in the background. Mainly because of his deep insights. Naturally, I wanted to read his work further and I was curious to read how the Vietnam war is felt and told through Vietnamese eyes.

While I’m not sure where he draws the line between his own horrible experience and artistic decisions, it obvious that most of his traumatizing experience as a soldier of the North Vietnam forces, had deeply scarred his life and soul.

It’s an agonizing story written simply and hauntingly, and a very short read that scatters different events and anecdotes, just like the running thoughts of a man remembering flashes from his war. In that sense, it’s not an epic tale or documentation, but flares of the horrors that got tattooed in himself forever.

The ending of the book, taking an artistic twist, is beautiful, sad, and very Tarkovskyian.

This book is yet one more testament of how wars scar young men and women for life, how it lives through them after it ends, and how vast is the tragic damage they cause to everyone’s life. (less)

An amazing book, especially for people interested in the history of the US war with Vietnam. This is a personal first-person account told from the point-of-view of a Vietnamese foot soldier (the author draws upon his experience as a Vietnamese foot soldier). It is not propaganda, nor is it US-bashing. It is a riveting fictional account of the peculiar specificities of that particular tradgedy of war. It is readable, if "gut-wrenching". It offers another view of that war, which Americans often only view from their specific point-of-view. The US lost almost 55,000 citizens in that war; Vietnam lost almost 3 million. One can say "well, the north vietnamese chose to fight that war and to send that many people to die in war"; the author does say this and even questions the logic and morality of the North Vietnamese leadership for doing so. This is another reason why this book is so important to read [especially in a time when a man who spent 6 years as a "high-value" American POW in the "Hanoi Hilton" is running as the Republican nominee for US president (this candidate has indicated that he still thinks that the wrong side won the war)]. (less)

This book is structured around a protagonist Kien and his attempt - through writing a novel after the war - to rid himself of his memories of the war and of his relationship with Phuong, his childhood sweetheart, and its gradual disintegration during and after the war.

Probably the overwhelming response of American readers to this book is that it humanizes the Vietnamese during the Vietnam War: and thank god. The most common explanation for North Vietnam's victory is that the North Vietnamese were determined to end centuries of colonization and willing to fight until they happened - in other words, that the war of attrition was a strategy that failed to understand that the North Vietnamese couldn't be worn down. So it's moving and emotional to read an account of a person disintegrating, who sees no point to much of the suffering he's surrounded by.

For me, reading about Kien and Phuong's relationship also gave Hanoi an interesting and young-feeling dimension, picturing it not just as an outsider for once but through the eyes of young kids on their bicycles riding past big West Lake young at sunset and in love. (less)

As you learn from the jacket, the author of this book was among the 10 survivors of the brigade of 500 soldiers he joined in 1969. So you know right away that this is not going to be an easy book to read, and it's not. It's difficult to read because the most horrible death and destruction stalks every page. But it's also literally hard to read, because it pretty much breaks all the rules of story-telling. There are no chapters, and little structure. It reads pretty much like a dream (a nightmare that is). You know the ending before you know all of its significance. It's a bit like a puzzle, and part of what keeps you reading is a desire for all the pieces to drop into place.

It was a terrible war, and the only hope in this book are the few instances when things could have been worse. To be honest, the only war stories I've read are a series of midieval warfare books that take place in Europe in the 1300's. But, given that inexperience, what seems to set this book apart from others for me is that the protagonist was our enemy, yet despite what we've been told, seems exactly like us. (less)

Comparable in some ways to All Quiet on the Western Front, rather than build up a plot, this book layers the reader's understanding of the soldier, Kien, before, during and after the Vietnam war, along with his teenage sweetheart Phuong. There are glimpses of the horror of war, the tormented mind afterwards of a veteran, told through snatches of stark, honest prose, where the enemy is not so much fighters on the other side of the battle, but war itself, and its swathe of destruction on a generation's mind and heart. Although there are occasional graphic war scenes, more raw is the emotional power seen through the lens of time when "The Jungle of Screaming Souls" is revisited through present and past images painted on a canvas that pulses in the reader's heart.
There are occasional sections where the descriptive narrative seems strained, or the images of a veteran's struggle seem more hollow than the rest of the book, but by and large this leaves the reader with a soaring loathing of those who force war onto the lives of the young, regardless of political ideology. (less)

Since it's written by a North Vietnamese Army veteran, this book is a chance to glimpse the other side of the Vietnam War and see our old enemies in a more human light--not simply as cannon fodder for 80's action movies. This is a passionate, disturbing book written in the tone of somebody who is utterly shell-shocked, thereby giving the narrative an almost dream-like quality which makes the atrocities of the story seem rather otherworldly and unreal. My one problem with the novel, though, is its structure. There is little overall story arc and events are recorded completely out of sequence, so it's easy to lose track of the novel's chronology. But that's definitely the way the author wanted it to be presented: as though his thoughts had been vomited onto the page rather than written down carefully. I'd recommend reading When Heaven and Earth Changed Places instead, but The Sorrow of War is nonetheless a haunting account of a dark time in world history. (less)

This novel of the Vietnam War is interesting for its graphic depictions of the war as it really was for the North Vietnamese soldiers, a civil war between North and South with the Americans an anonymous mass threatening from a distance but rarely the focus. Ninh's writing leaps around in time without any attempt to coherently link events for the reader which gives a fantastic insight into the mind of a soldier destroyed by war, but also makes this a difficult book to understand. Perhaps that is its point. The love story between Kien and Phuong, both little more than children at the war's outbreak, is movingly tender when set against so much violence and their loss of innocence could just as well apply to the whole country that was ripped apart by over a decade of conflict. (less)

The amount of are emotion pushed into this novel is heart-breaking. The author strips away the polished facade of Communist propoganda and gives the reader an unabashed view of the soldiers fighting in a troubled war. The story is told through short stories and brief images seemingly put together at random, and does this to heighten the experience, to live through the thoughts of the character.
I really enjoyed the book for what it was, gritty and shameless look at the war from a North Vietnamese soldier. Pain and sadness flow through it, across the language barrier. It's a solid read not only for the paradigm shift, but also for the deep emotional journey, rich and complex as it was. (less)

A very deep and meaningful book, the Sorrow of War isn't a light read and one that requires a lot of thought. The structure of the story itself, out of chronological order, is very confusing and sometimes took my interest away from the actual storyline as I tried to figure out where in time we were, but what is interesting is that the author explains (sort of) why he wrote it like this. Because it's a novel for IB English, it's naturally depressing but it was still a good book by itself, although I probably wouldn't read it again. (less)

Kiên, a soldier who returns to his home after the war struggles to live. Bảo Ninh is such a great writer, I can feel almost like I was living in the middle of the war. The war where Kiên and his comrades experienced. If you are planning to read this book then you should prepare to read many violent or sexual scenes. The book reflects the hidden story of the war. There is nothing such as glory or victory. No one ever wins a war. What can I say about this book? A truly masterpiece. I would recommend this book to every Vietnamese or anyone who is interested in Vietnamese literature. (less)

An outstanding book from the North Vietnamese perspective during the American war and after. I teach this with O'Brien's "The Things They Carried" and the similarities are many, yet they are clearly different books. Ninh has a challenging writing style to get into, but once you are in it is easy to meander through his memories and time changes. This book was banned in Vietnam when it came out, but still became very popular. Just an excellent novel. (less)

Interesting to think of the war in Vietnam told from the North Vietnamese perspective, and so this novel presents a novel point-of-view, and the last fifty pages are legitimately affecting. In that light, it's plenty effective. That said, there are spots throughout where either melodrama or melodramatic translation forces the prose into cliches and lessens the impact of Bao Ninh's achievement here. (less)

I've read plenty of Vietnam books, but this was the first one told from the POV of a Vietcong footslogger. It has a lot in common with Das Boot in its clinical realism and willingness to admit the dull parts of warfare. The Vietcong aren't portrayed as saints or the American soldiers as devils. The day to day minutiae of warfare, where the grandest objective is to live long enough to enjoy another ciggy, is enough. (less)

This story about everything war destroys: love, friendship, trust, sanity, lives, is being written in an impressive way. The stories are haunting me already for days, and hearing now a non-american voice is a relief. What an achievement and what an impact...

I should give this 4 stars, because it is a horribly good book. But it was so hard to enjoy reading it, and I came out of it full of grief, not wanting to dwell. Am I glad I read it? Yes. Will I ever read it again? No.

This book was beautifully and compellingly written; however, the raw brutality of almost each and every scene was too much for me. I am sure the book is very accurate - war is overwhelmingly brutal - I just had a hard time dealing with it.
Brutal, harrowing and lyrical; disorienting combination.
Beautifully written, haunting and tragically sad.

Absolutely extraordinary book, which shocked, saddened and devastated me. The storytelling was immediately immersive and involved a nostalgic yet tragic romance, thrilling and terrifying war reports, and brutally honest reflections from one man heavily involved in the violent upheaval of his country.

Extremely autobiographical, but actually historical fiction, Bao Ninh tells the story of Kien. Kien was a soldier in the American War in Vietnam, fighting for Communist North Vietnam - but this book was banned by the Communist party because of its critical and personal perspective. When we first meet him, it is towards the end of the war and he is in the Jungle of Screaming Souls, collecting and identifying bodies. The mood is melancholy and ethereal - he cannot sleep because he is haunted by memories and ghosts of dead comrades and current corpses he sleeps above in his truck as he gathers the dead.

Although our author has difficulty distinguishing reality, his recollections are vivid and violent. Check out this passage from page 3: "The diamond–shaped glass clearing was piled high with bodies killed by helicopter gunships. Broken bodies, bodies blown apart, bodies vaporized. No jungle grew again in this clearing. No grass. No plants. “Better to die than surrender my brothers? Better to die?” the battalion commander yelled insanely; waving his pistol in front of Kien he blew his own brains out through his ear. Kien screamed soundlessly in his throat at the sight, as the Americans attacked with submachine guns, sending bullets buzzing like deadly bees around him. Then Kien lowered his machine gun, grasped his side and fell, rolling slowly down the bank of a shallow stream, hot blood trailing down the slope after him (Ninh, 5)." That's page THREE guys. You are immediately thrust into the awful action of an atrocious war, and though the horror continues, it really actually deepens as we discover more about our author and his experiences.

The story doesn't have chapters and it switches from first to third person perspective frequently - its actually the story of him writing a story of his memoirs from the war, and we learn more about his personal past (childhood, relationship with parents, early romance, etc) through his reflections. He feels haunted by his history and has survivor's guilt, and realizes midway through the book that he must write a book to process, recover and redeem himself. Characters dead reappear as he fleshes out their role, and his past lover from childhood reappears in the present time. The story circles and doubles back on itself often, representing the role of memory in an individual, and also the PTSD of a solider whose existence and country has been totally redefined by war.

But this isn't just about soldiers - in this book, and in this war historically, we are forced to focus on the ways that civilian lives have been wrecked and ruined and redefined by the tragedy of war. He doesn't delve into details - he is up-front and forward with the full exposure which war brings to simple people, and doesn't need to dress it up with disclaimers or details. Surviving soldiers live paralyzed and permanently scarred lives, mothers are devastated by losing multiple children or entire households...everyone is affected to an awful extent...

There are multiple subplots, notably with his father and with his childhood sweetheart, which delve more deeply into the psychological catastrophes which each person endures due to the war, and we recognize over and over that the sorrow of war has nothing to do with wins and losses, statistics, timelines, or death tolls; but rather, the ruin which indiscriminately redefines each individual.

This book is beautifully written and effectively agonizing. As a pacifist, it persuaded me even more in my sentiments. As someone who lived in Vietnam two years, it broke my heart but built up my amazement at their recovery and forgiveness of foreign oppressors. As a book lover, I was swept away by the tragic tone, the clever circular delivery of the narrative and the layers of meaning. As someone who empathized with the author, it made me want to be more courageous in love as I read about the boldness of destruction and The Sorrow of War.

War is hell. And here is why.

There is no shortage of media content made about the Vietnam War. You find it in music, books, and video games. You find it in pop culture. However, you almost exclusively find it described from a perspective of an American. And like most of the war content anywhere, it is unnaturally romanticized. War is noble. War is awesome. War is a fight for freedom. War has clear winners and obvious losers. The archetype of a war hero is a virtuous and honorable warrior that easily tells right from wrong, fights for justice, and in the end, returns to the happy, healthy family that eagerly awaits for him, safe and sound.

Well, no. It is not like that. At all.

This book tells a story from a viewpoint of a Northern Vietnamese soldier, a youngling named Kieu. He leaves his family, his education and his high-school love to go fight in a bloody, merciless conflict against his rebellious compatriots and foreign invaders.

Like the war itself, this book is chaotic. Timeline is non-existent. The stories inside are jaw-dropping in the most horrendous way. The veneer of civilization is scraped away so many times and the horrifying nature of the human animal is shown beneath, explicitly showing all the acts of brutality people are ready to commit once the fog of war engulfs the nation. Rape and slaughter, mayhem and murder, that is the reality of this conflict that Bao Ninh vividly portrays here.

Hand-in-hand with macabre depictions of war times, there are other excerpts of pre-war events that show what life looked like before the carnage started. First loves, happy families, plans of the future. It is all here, but it doesn't serve the purpose of giving this book merry overtones or an idea of a happy ending. There are here to turn the volume up on the melancholic tune and to crystalize the central theme of this book: the sorrow of war. Everything that war, any war, takes away.

In one of his novels, famous American writer Kurt Vonnegut compared writing anti-war books to writing anti-glacier books because „there would always be wars, that they were as easy to stop as glaciers“. This book dismisses that notion and through vivid descriptions and reminiscence subtly embraces one of the finest anti-war rhetoric I have seen. And even if it fails in that intention, it still serves as a stark reminder that once the war starts, no soldier on the field is a winner.

If you ever plan to read The Sorrow of War in English—the version in which it is most read, way more than the original, which was banned until 2006 in Vietnam—you should know that what is called a “translation” by Frank Palmos is more of a re-writing. Phan Thanh Hao produced a raw translation of Bao Ninh’s book. Then, an Australian journalist named Frank Palmos wrote an English version based on the raw translation. For what it’s worth, Bao Ninh agreed with this arrangement and met with both guys several times. Most translations are based on what Palmos wrote, except for a version in French, Japanese, and Chinese, or so Wikipedia tells me. I’m sure some of my friends who study comparative literature & translation theory can present actual arguments for whether this is a Good or a Bad thing, but personally, I’m inclined to feel annoyed about all of this.

Now that I cautioned you… I’m not sure how much is lost or invented in translation, but what I read in Vietnamese, written by Bao Ninh, is a great novel, not a piece of propaganda or a textbook on the Vietnam War. Literature should be something else, something more than politics or even history—and this was it.

This novel was an assigned reading for my HIS 112 class during the period in which we covered the Vietnam War. Bảo Ninh writes about Kien, a North Vietnamese soldier, who details his life within the scope of war in a manuscript; from prewar, during war, and postwar.

One of the most noticeable features of the book is that it is not written in chronological order and also does not have any chapters or other obvious stopping points besides line breaks. Although confusing and hard to follow at first (I should preface that I have not had any experience with this writing style before), the intentions behind this stylistic choice are explained within the novel, both by Kien and an unnamed character that appears towards the end. This style is meant to encapsulate the inner monologue and glimpses of the past that appear to Kien.

Kien is not the perfect protagonist either; his innocence and timidness slowly fade as rage and sorrow take over his mind over the course of the war, influencing his actions and words. By the end, he is a broken man and slips into alcoholism to cope with his PTSD.

The novel covers several themes including sacrifice, trauma, loss, grief, love, comradeship and paints them very vividly as we journey with Kien across his "river of life." As the title implies, this book is very sorrowful and heavy; it can weigh the soul down. Definitely take your time with it, step back, and reflect as Kien does.

I believe this piece would also be an interesting reread as it is not in chronological order as previously mentioned. Some of the characters and locations were briefly introduced towards the beginning of the novel with not much context surrounding them only to be delved deeper into within the story.
