The Aesthetics of Remembering the Dead and the Loving
by Van A. Huebner

(Tim O’Brien’s The Things They Carried
and
Bao Ninh’s The Sorrow of War)

Timothy O’Brien and Bao Ninh provide us with a good opportunity to demonstrate what I propose to investigate more thoroughly at some other time. But for the purposes of the moment let me digress a little and begin by referring to M. Merleau-Ponty’s, Phenomenology of Perception. M-P mentions the difficulty of knowing more than one language and states that one “never does belong to two worlds at once [while he does acknowledge] selves conversing in the void [...when] madness is very near.”

“It is impossible to superimpose on man a lower layer of behavior which one chooses to call ‘natural,’ followed by a manufactured cultural or spiritual world. Everything is both manufactured and natural in man, as it were, in the sense that there is not a word, not a form of behavior which does not owe something to purely biological being―and which at the same time does not elude the simplicity of animal life, and cause forms of vital behavior to deviate from their pre-ordained direction, through a sort of leakage and through a genius for ambiguity which might serve to define man [....] It is impossible to draw up an inventory of this irrational power which creates meanings and conveys them.”
[M. Merleau-Ponty, Phenomenology of Perception]

While I would agree to the impossibility of such an inventory of powers, I would argue that this “power of giving shape to stimuli and situations[...]” and this leakage are precisely what the two authors in question have done and exemplify―an organic, symbolic re-combination and differentiation of fact. Firstly, the authors resided as it were in two worlds at once, their former civilized world of kindness and calm, yet also in a world of an animalistic indiscretion and violence, the inhumanity of cruelty, brutality. They have seen the real result of war, the spillage of blood, they know intimately the “leakage,” thus the feeling of that “vital force [which] flowed from [Kien].” And yet as well the being caught up in the flow―such as when, in The Things They Carried, "life seemed to be collapsing toward slaughter [....] All around me the options seemed to be narrowing, as if I were hurtling down a huge black funnel, the whole world squeezing in tight." [Tim O’Brien] These authors then, through their main characters, show this dual belonging that can exist for creatures forced to endure the extraordinary, the upside down and foul doctrine of war: killing is acceptable and required―and that they must retain the previous moral stability as well so as to revert to it when the killing is finished.

This residing in two worlds at once exists as well for any fiction writer in a sense. They must maintain a ‘hold on reality,’ as they say, while they imagine another. In order to fashion this other world they must have more than just lingual skill, but also the psychic power to pass between both worlds at a given moment such as required to sustain them both. A power which at times is as heavy as the burden their protagonists carry: “If only he could shed all other needs of everyday living and concentrate all his energies into writing[...]” about the carrying of this burden―this retelling of this horrible condition that all soldiers endure―for it may indeed have been a “sacred duty” [Bao Ninh] for the writer to endure and survive such “Sorrow...”

Both O’Brien and Bao have also attempted to describe this very difficult task of remaining sane while being torn apart between these two moral worlds that they experienced, by allowing their protagonist to live out the ambiguity of it. The landscape then becomes the symbolic inversion of this: “Rivers of fire,” “peace [as] a tree that thrives only on the blood and bones”― such that Kien can see the “beautiful landscape of calm and peace [as] an appalling paradox;” or after war it is the “soft surfaces” that bring back the memory of it. There is as well the symbolic conjugation between the two worlds: such as when O'Brien's Kiowa, first flesh, then all at once swallowed up by the earth, becomes one with the war. The author by seeing it thus comes back more complete, but inevitably much heavier for these ghosts that cling to him. While the soldier must sustain an extraordinary self-composure during this time of war, this extraordinary time; his psychic makeup all along, his ordinary upbringing, is telling him that his behavior is akin to the hangman’s or the serial killer’s in his otherwise ordinary times to which he must return.
The writer as well must slip through the psychic membrane of the reader without rupturing this delicate attentive bubble. And it must be done by maintaining an extraordinary and supple voice overall in order to implant what might even in the end be the inability-to-circumscribe reality as it was a priori the conceiving of it. This seed of truth is something other than an inventory of facts; and once an author dissects it, the totality of facts become a new truth. This the artist must relate to a reader’s satisfaction without too much sacrifice or leakage. Otherwise the objectification becomes as Mishima’s apple or Wittgenstein’s ladder, and we must then confess that we’ve failed to convey anything at all but the de-constructive process.
In a sense we could say these are novels of the ultimate rite of passage. Passage in the ordinary sense would have us recalling the freshets of childhood and the wild adolescence that might once have caused us to grimace, but now perhaps elicit only a smirk, or a chuckle. But crushes and pining become uncommon in true literature. And these crossings over take us neither to Canada; nor merely deeper into a dark continent. These are not ordinary rivers and jungle paths. And they are neither an anthropologist’s quaint ‘soul catching’ of, nor ‘vision quest’ for, representative spirits. These are the kindred morphs of modernism sheared, a consecration of living’s defilement; as the artists fairly say “to the Worm: Thou art my mother and my sister,” [William Blake] both Timothy O’Brien and Bao Ninh find redemption in the aesthetics of remembering the dead and the loving. This is the single most beautiful, touching, nightmarish, horrifying book I have ever read.

The true nightmare of war, as described by Ninh, isn't merely the barbarism of violence itself, but the way every moment of one's life is irrevocably lashed to it. War is not a neat chapter of one's life, like a chapter of a book with a beginning and an end, instead the tendrils of its memory coil around every moment of one's life. Every passing moment ignites a memory of a fellow soldier, brain hollowed out by enemy rounds or drowned to death in a swamp or worse. There is no aspect of your life that remains untouched, except perhaps the memories of life before war, pure in their innocence. But in those memories lies madness too, because those youthful moments are not preserved in amber, waiting for your return. They, too, have been destroyed.

The prose here is gutting, filled with a sort of matter-of-fact sorrow that just sort of hurts to read. A loose, rambling structure, in which one memory naturally follows another, only further emphasizes the unyielding corruption of war. No matter where you stand, what you do, who you see, what you choose to remember and what you hope to forget, your mind will inevitably slink past it back into thoughts of ghosts.

MAY 28, 2021 CounterPunch
The Long Silence of Bao Ninh
By Rohit Inani.

In the fall of 2018, Rohit Inani, a freelance journalist based in New Delhi, contacted CounterPunch contributor Marc Levy after reading his 1998 interview with Bao Ninh. Rohit, who admires Ninh’s work, asked to be put in touch with Ninh. Several weeks later, with help from the Joiner Institute, and the Vietnamese Writer’s Association, Rohit interviewed Ninh in Hanoi. Since Bao Ninh famously avoids the press, Rohit’s essay, first published in the 1 September 2018 issue of The Caravan, an Indian monthly magazine with presence in other South Asian countries, is a major literary event.
Bao Ninh settled into his chair and ordered for tea. He put a pack of Camel cigarettes on the table and looked out of the window. “It’s not a good time to come to Hanoi,” he said.

May in the city is hot and stifling, and marks the beginning of a sweltering summer. As the temperatures soar, the crowds fizzle out. Later, the monsoon rains wash the city, igniting the “spirit of Hanoi,” which, according to Kien—the protagonist of The Sorrow of War, Ninh’s daring and wildly popular 1990 novel based on his experiences in the Vietnam war—is “strongest by night, even stronger in the rain. Like now, when the whole town seems deserted, wet, lonely, cold, and deeply sad.”

We met at a cafe in downtown Hanoi, favoured by journalists, artists, and middle-ranking officials of the Communist Party of Vietnam, which has ruled the country since the end of the war in 1975. Ninh rarely engages with the press or gives interviews, preferring a quiet and simple life in Hanoi, which he seldom leaves. Outside, on the street, a light wind blew and the sun shone on the window pane, occasionally capturing Ninh’s attention. He lit a cigarette. “I appreciate your efforts and your interest in me, but there is not much to say,” he said to me through his interpreter Nguyen Phoung Loan. “I’m a writer. I can write but I’m not very good at talking about myself.”

Ninh is handsome, with a thatch of wavy, ash-grey hair and deep, glum eyes. “Shall we begin?” he said. “Don’t have much time. I might have to undergo a surgery tomorrow.” In the first week of May, Ninh was diagnosed with a cancerous tumor, the consequence of years of dependence on alcohol and tobacco, a habit he acquired after he returned home from the war, to a troubled post-war life, writing and drinking from night till dawn in his home, at the time a squalid pad in Central Hanoi.

Ninh, who will turn sixty-six this October, is Vietnam’s most celebrated writer, best-known for The Sorrow of War, which was immediately deemed a classic of war narrative when published in English in 1994, earning comparisons with Erich Maria Remarque’s famous All Quiet on The Western Front, a novel about the experiences of German soldiers during the First World War. Based on Ninh’s time as a North Vietnamese soldier, who served with the Glorious 27th Youth brigade—of the five hundred who went to war in 1969, Ninh was one of the ten who survived; of these, six later committed suicide—the novel recounts the experiences of its anti-hero, Kien, a middle-aged war veteran chronicling his war memories while collecting the bodies of his fallen comrades in the jungles of Central Vietnam. In 1994, Ninh became the first Vietnamese writer to win an overseas literary prize when The Sorrow of War bagged The Independent Foreign Fiction Prize, trumping Italo Calvino’s The Road to San Giovanni, among others. At the awards ceremony in Hay-on-Wye, Robert Winder, then the literary editor of The Independent, called the novel “historic,” and remarked, while announcing the award: “Usually, history is the story told by the winners; Bao Ninh’s book reminds us that, in war, everybody loses.”

At the end of the Second World War, Vietnam, which had been a French colony, fought the French for independence, led by Ho Chi Minh and his communist front Viet Minh. In 1954, after the Viet Minh forces defeated France, the war was settled by the signing of the Geneva Accords, which also temporarily divided Vietnam along a latitude commonly referred to as the seventeenth parallel. Determined to unify Vietnam and drive out the “American imperialists,” Ho Chi Minh—meaning the “bringer of light”—intensified his attacks on the South, which was at the time supported by the United States and led by the anti-communist leader Ngo Dinh Diem. This began the twenty-year conflict in 1955 between the communist-ruled north and the south. The Cold War was also ongoing at the time, and the Vietnamese conflict ricocheted inside the hallways of Pentagon. In 1965, fearing a communist victory in Vietnam, the United States dispatched the first combat troops to the country. The ensuing war raged for a decade and exacted a huge human toll, especially on the Vietnamese side. On 30 April 1975, at noon, Saigon fell. As news of victory filtered to the north, people hit the streets, waving flags and cheering, “Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh! Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh!”

As the sounds of victory dimmed, Vietnam, finally reunited after decades of war, came to terms with the price it had paid to realize a long-cherished dream. The country had been devastated, its cities and towns ruined by unabated aerial bombings. Five million hectares of forests and vegetation were destroyed by high-grade explosives and chemicals, including an estimated forty-three million litres of Agent Orange. Over three million Vietnamese people had been killed. And with plummeting Soviet aid at a time of international isolation, the nation’s socialist economic model had completely collapsed. In 1986, after almost a decade of high inflation and widespread poverty, the Communist Party took measures to liberalise the economy, a move that became known as the Doi Moi reforms, and led Vietnam, two decades later, to become one of the world’s fastest-growing economies. In 2008, The Economist called it “Asia’s other miracle” after China.

The current generation of Vietnamese adults is too young to remember the war. On the margins of this shift stands Ninh, author of the country’s most cherished war novel, who not only spoke to the generation that fought the war, but humanised its victims, and in doing so, broke away from Vietnamese officialdom, which remained a cocktail of patriotism, glory, and propaganda. At the height of the war, radio broadcasts in Hanoi and most of north Vietnam described the war as “just,” asked for the “devotion” of the North Vietnamese Army troops toward the Communist Party, and routinely referred to the south as a “puppet” administration of the United States. On 5 March 1969, a regular bulletin on Hanoi Radio, one of the few radio stations operating out of Hanoi at the time, called on the soldiers, whom it described as “compatriots,” to show that “their absolute loyalty to the Party and the Revolution has helped … develop … resourcefulness and liveliness in fighting and vanquishing the enemy.” After the end of the war, the official party discourse focused on the heroic efforts of the soldiers and their sacrifice for the country, but suppressed stories of their suffering and cruelty during the war.

“It was crucial when it came out and remains crucial today, when many Vietnamese either do not know anything about their wartime past or would choose to forget what they know,” Viet Thanh Nguyen, the Pulitzer prize-winning Vietnamese-American writer, told me over email. But while an entire generation is putting its past behind it, attempting to find a new national identity, Ninh is reluctant to move on. In Hanoi, I interviewed several of his friends, writers and veterans, most of whom spoke of his two defining traits, traits that have remained unchanged for years: his silence, his sadness.

One afternoon, over vodka and endless cigarettes in the conference room of the Vietnam Writers’ Association, an official culture association under the Communist Party, some of Ninh’s closest writer friends sat at a long teakwood table and waited for lunch to be served. Most of the gathered were member associates.

“Ninh is always silent. He never talks about his book, his writing, anything. We all are used to it,” Nguyen Chi Hoan said. “You never ask him why?” I asked. He laughed. “We don’t dare ask him that! Here, we respect and appreciate his silence.” Hoan pointed to Dao Ba Doan and urged him to speak. “He has spent a lot of time with Bao Ninh! Mr. Doan, tell us about Bao Ninh,” he said, in jest. Doan, a poet, popped open a can of beer, took a long swill and then slowly jutted out his right arm horizontally, then swung it toward his head, the tip of his index finger stiff and perpendicular to his temple. “There is still a big sorrow in his head,” he said. “Only Vietnamese can understand the sorrow in his mind.” Others let out sighs and nodded in agreement. Then, breaking the silence in the room, the doors were thrown open. “Ah! Ân trưa ở đây!”—“Ah, lunch is here!” Doan said.

KIEN, THE NARRATOR OF The Sorrow of War, joins the NVA in 1969 at the age of twenty-one, at a time when a patriotic wave is sweeping Vietnam in response to the enemy invasion. He joins Battalion 27, a unit comprising five hundred mostly young men, and in the dry season of that year, the whole group is almost entirely decimated by napalm fires in the jungle. In 1976, after the end of the war, Kien returns to the Central Highlands as part of the Missing In Action body collecting team and, on board a Russian-built Zil truck, reaches the Jungle of Screaming Souls. At one point, still somewhat hopeful for the future, Kien asks the truck driver, “But isn’t peace better than war?” to which he replies:
“This kind of peace? In this kind of peace it seems people have unmasked themselves and revealed their true, horrible selves. So much blood, so many lives were sacrificed for what?”
“Damn it, what are you trying to say?’ Kien asked.

“I’m not trying to say anything. I’m simply a soldier like you who’ll now have to live with broken dreams and with pain. But, my friend, our era is finished. After this hard-won victory fighters like you, Kien, will never be normal again. You won’t even speak with your normal voice, in the normal way again.”

Ninh, like Kien, enlisted with the NVA at the age of seventeen after dropping out of high school in 1969. He was among the thousands of young men who answered the call of the Communist Party to fight the Americans and unify Vietnam. Ninh answered the call “just like any other Vietnamese at the time,” he told me, cigarette smoke spiraling around his face. “You were eager and excited to do that.” When he showed up at the recruiting camp, he was greeted by performers singing songs of glory, drumming up the patriotic spirit of the young fighters. By the time the war ended, the soldiers who survived returned to the North as victors. They were hailed as heroes by the government, but Ninh came back devastated. “Each day brought new nightmares; even my parents feared me. I was keen to forget the war, but it refused to release its grip on me,” he told a gathering at the Southeast Asian Literature Forum in Taiwan this March.

In the novel, as Kien recalls his fallen comrades, he comes to grip with the horrors of war, and while moving month after month through the “mountains and jungles, water-soaked and dull… muddy as all hell,” ghosts are resurrected as the wandering dead, who come to haunt the living. “The dead step from every corner, every house, every jungle trail, creating a narrative structure that feels like a tide coming in and washing out—relentless—more like labyrinth upon labyrinth than any solid Aristotelian form,” noted the Canadian novelist Madeleine Thien, writing about the novel on the PEN America website.

Ninh rejects narrative conventions in The Sorrow of War, adopting a highly non-linear structure, shifting between past and present in an effort to collapse and immobilize time. Later in the novel, Kien begins to write a book and eventually finds that “the act of writing blurs his neat designs, finally washing them away altogether, or blurs them so the lines become intermixed and sequences lose their order.”

Viet Thanh Nguyen elaborated on this aspect of the novel over email.

Linear, coherent storytelling in regards to the war and the revolution are the features of government-sanctioned storytelling, in films, novels, and especially historical museums. This kind of storytelling pins all the blame on enemy outsiders and internal traitors, and paints the soldiers, guerrillas, and revolutionaries as optimistic, noble patriots. Bao Ninh’s novel tells a radically different story about how these young patriots were utterly destroyed by the war. That much is coherent. But when one is utterly destroyed, can one be coherent? That core trauma is ultimately revealed by the end, and we finally understand why the novel could not be narrated in a linear fashion. This is a terrific move by a novelist who understands, implicitly or explicitly, how trauma works.

“The war is like an obsession for him,” Pham Xuan Nguyen, a writer and a popular literary critic in Hanoi, told me. “Whatever he writes, it will be about the war. Ninh is the kind of person who needs to be thrown into such events like the war … to become a writer. And this war—if I’m not exaggerating—has chosen him to write about it.”

Pham occasionally paused as we talked, as if trying to find the perfect words to describe the indescribable: the post-war years in Vietnam and his longtime friend, Ninh. “For Vietnamese soldiers, when you returned, there were two things that caused them trauma,” he said. “First was the question of why they were still alive when their comrades had died. Second, is life in peacetime better than death in the war?”

In The Sorrow of War, after Kien returns to Hanoi, he looks back at his years, and reminisces.
From now on life may be always dark, full of suffering, with brief moments of happiness. Living somewhere between a dream world and reality, on the knife-edge between the two. I’ve lived all these lost years. No one to blame for that. Not me, not anyone else…There’s a new life ahead of me, and a new era for Vietnam. I have to survive. But my soul is still in turmoil.

Thrust into the world amidst the sounds of bombs exploding, Ninh was born in 1952, on the day the French attacked his village in the Nghe An province, west of the gulf of Tonkin. After the defeat of the French army and their subsequent withdrawal from North Vietnam in 1954, his family moved to Hanoi. His father—who was a lifelong communist and a party member—was the director of the Vietnam’s Linguistics Institute. Ninh considers his father an influence, and he came of age in a house that resembled “a jungle of books,” Nguyen Quang Thieu, a poet and vice president of the writers’ association, told me.

“It was mostly children’s books that I read while growing up.” Ninh said. “It was the time of the Cold War and there were not many translations of foreign literature available. Mostly I read the Russians. Some from China. Jack London. I enjoyed reading Erich Maria Remarque. Nguyen Tuan was my favourite writer.”

I asked Ninh whether he had had any literary ambitions at the time. “I’d have become a different person. Not a writer. I was seventeen. Who would have thought I will become a writer one day?” he replied. “War is the opposite of literature, of writing.” He paused and fidgeted with the cigarette pack. “It’s hard to determine how you become someone in your life… Had I not gone to the war, I wouldn’t have much to say, much to write about.”

In 1975, after spending years on the war-ravaged Ho Chi Minh trail, and being witness to some of the most intense and brutal fighting, Ninh ended up with the NVA regiment that had earlier bombed and captured the Tan Son Nhut airport in Saigon. He returned to Hanoi in 1981 and began writing after a few years. For a brief time he worked odd jobs in the city’s old quarter, sometimes selling bicycles, Phan Thanh Hao, a poet and one of his translators into English, told me.

Ninh struggled to write. “I was not good with words and could not express the pain deep in my heart,” he told the gathering in Taiwan. “It took me a decade to gather the courage to put The Sorrow of War down on paper.” Ninh briefly enrolled in a writing course at the Nguyen Du Writers School—named in honour of the famed Vietnamese poet—and it was here that he wrote his most famous book, as part of his graduation project.

After Ninh finished the manuscript, it began circulating in Hanoi in a roneo form—a stencil duplicate similar to photocopy—and was published in 1990 under the title Than Phan Cua Tinh Yeu or The Destiny of Love. The book immediately became popular in Vietnam, even winning the Writers’ Association prize the following year. “You can understand the enthusiasm for this book in Vietnam. It is free of propaganda and politics. It does not romanticize the war, and yet the author looks back to those ‘caring days, when we knew what we were living and fighting for and why we needed to suffer and sacrifice,’” the author Michael Fathers wrote in The Independent in 1994. It came to the attention of Phan Thanh Hao, who decided to translate the book into English. Immediately after, the novel became controversial for its portrayal of the war and was banned in Vietnam by the Communist Party, which even retracted the literary prize. In 1995, a former NVA veteran told The New York Times, “I became very angry at Bao Ninh. Why did Bao Ninh write about the war so everyone could see its naked face?”

The English-language manuscript—which, according to some accounts, was smuggled out of Vietnam by a young British translator in Hanoi—landed on the desk of Geoffrey Mulligan, then an editor at Secker and Warburg in London. He rang up Frank Palmos, an Australian war correspondent, and asked if he knew Bao Ninh. “Of course,” Palmos said. “I had coffee with him just yesterday in Hanoi.” Mulligan commissioned Palmos—who had covered the Vietnam war and published a book about it, Ridding the Devils—to write an English version based on the raw translation by Hao. When the book appeared in Europe and North America, it caused a sensation, for this was the first time that Vietnamese soldiers had been shown to have suffered as much as the Americans. “It was a way of letting the world know that even if we had won the war, deep inside us we knew we didn’t,” Phan Thanh Hao told me. Bao Ninh joined the North Vietnamese Liberation Army (NVA) in 1969 as a member of a 500-man brigade; by war’s end in 1975 he was one of only ten survivors. The Sorrow of War: A Novel of Vietnam (1991) is his story of Kien, a soldier in the NVA from 1965 through the end of the war in 1975. Kien is clearly the author’s doppelganger, the ghost at Bao’s side as he wrote the novel. Kien is looking back from his vantage in 1990, remembering his comrades, counting his losses, living not for his future but for his memories so that his dead comrades might not permanently disappear.

This novel is both haunting and beautiful in its description of the terrors of war in a harsh terrain with constant bad weather, with very limited resources, and with constant political indoctrination—as if an army marches on its politics, not its stomach. Like most soldiers who’ve experienced combat, Kien is trapped in the war long after its end. He writes,
Since returning to Hanoi [in 1975] I’ve had to live with this parade of horrific memories, day after day, long night after long night. For how many years now? For how many more years? . . . From the horizon of the distant past an immense sad wind, like an endless sorrow, gusts and blows through the villages, through the cities, and through my life.
Kien was a platoon commander, equivalent to a lieutenant, responsible for three squads of patrol scouts, about forty men. He had to know his men both inside and out, to anticipate their actions and reactions, and to bolster their spirits and contain their excesses. So through Kien we learn about the NVA men of war, and we learn the burden that such intimate knowledge carries in war.

The staging area for Kien’s brigade was in “The Jungle of Screaming Souls." (Indications suggest that this was around Ngoc Linh , a four-peaked mountain at the “roof of South Vietnam” near Laos and Cambodia. There Kien and his comrades spent long months in rain, heat, humidity and isolation preparing for action, attending political lectures, and anticipating their own deaths by dreaming of the voices of their lost comrades, praying to their lost comrades—and by playing cards; their sole deck of cards was to be buried with the last to die.

During the pauses some men deserted, like Can who set off to find his mother in Hanoi and was found days later only a two-hour walk from the camp, already a near skeleton enmeshed in vegetation. Other platoon members found some solace in the jungle, like several soldiers who connected with three young Vietnamese farm girls for wild times, then murdered them. Kien survived an entire decade of life in combat: moments of extreme violence and terror, stretches of boredom awaiting terror, constant losses of friends and piecemeal disappearance of his soul.

Perhaps his worst period, his "year of suffering, was the Year of the Monkey, 1968. This was when North Vietnam shifted the war from rural areas to the southern cities. The year began with the Tet Offensive, followed by "Second Tet" and several “Mini-Tets.” It was North Vietnam’s Big Push, expected to incite South Vietnamese to rise up and join the Northern cause. As we know, Tet failed dismally in eliciting a ground swell of popular support, and the joint NVA-VC forces paid a high price. North Vietnam was badly mauled militarily but, in one of those historic ironies, it changed the American public's image of the war and was a major step toward winning the war politically.

The Sorrow of War is not a traditional story of combat in the vein of William Manchester’s Goodbye Darkness (1979), E. B. Sledge’s With the Old Breed: at Peleilu and Okinawa (1981), or Karl Marlantes’ more recent Matterhorn (2009)—all very powerful books by Marines. This is a story about the price the soul pays for the extended periods of physical and psychological turmoil that war demands, about the dehumanization that makes for success in war and utter failure in peace; today we would trivialize that price as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

Bao is eloquent as he describes both the agony and the release found in writing about his (Kien’s?) experiences—the constant tossing-out and rewriting and the constant reliving of the war as he writes and rewrites. His eloquence raises this novel far above the pedestrian “Woe is me” that can be the downfall of war memoirs.

Five Stars—absolutely! (less)

In an open stream of conscious style this novel tells the story of a North Vietnamese soldier who is collecting dead bodies after a battle and then begins to think about his past, his war past. What follows is a series of flashbacks that tell how Kien came to be here and what happened to his fallen comrades weaved together by he love affair between Kien and his childhood sweetheart, Phuong. Throughout the book, Kien also reflects on the many unacknowledged sacrifices, such as Hoa giving up her life to save Kien and his comrades from American soldiers, and acts of immorality and desecration, such as the objectification and treatment of a dead woman in the airport, that he experienced in the war. The novel ends with a passage by a new narrator, who explains that he has received Kien's novel from the mute girl. Although fiction the 1990 novel draws much of its inspiration from the author, Bảo Ninh's own war experience, ten years of combat in the Vietnam War (to him, the American War). A beautifully written narrative it provides a deeper perspective of what when on in those jungles of South East Asia all those years ago.

I first read this book as a part of my curriculum in my English class two years ago. The vast majority of writing about the Vietnam War published in the West has been from a US perspective. This book acts as a kind of corrective as, here, the US, along with the South Vietnamese ARVN, is the enemy. The novel’s viewpoint character is a North Vietnamese soldier, Kien, whom we first meet in his post-war duty of collecting for burial the remains of corpses left over from the war. This is in an eerie place the soldiers named the Jungle of Screaming Souls. One corpse is discovered in a colourless plastic bag and the body seems immaculate. Then it discolours, something seems to escape, and it deflates. The platoon takes this apparition as a soul departing. This scene is emblematic as, while the memories of combat are no doubt authentic, so much of what Binh describes here is surreal. Many descriptions of war are.

The novel is disjointed, fragmented, as if reflecting the uncanny nature of such experiences. Ninh tells us the sorrow of war is like the sorrow of love, “a kind of nostalgia,” a “sadness, a missing, a pain which could send one soaring back into the past.” The novel is a patchwork of such pain, of things unforgettable, surfacing unbidden from memory. “His fighting life was being revived in flashbacks, or in slowly unfolding scenes as heart-rending as a funeral march.” War as an experience is perhaps best encapsulated when Kien remembers trying to dissuade his comrade Can from deserting as it would be shameful. Can replied, “‘In all my time as a soldier I’ve yet to see anything honourable.’”

While combat and its horrors - the blood and entrails carried on the tracks of tanks so that they have to be driven through a river to clean them, Kien’s friend killed when his tank is all-but vapourised by a shell, the dreamlike quality of being on the receiving end of a US air-raid, the self-sacrifice of an inexperienced female guide named Hua who distracted a platoon of US soldiers away from a group of wounded NVA personnel whom she had put in danger of discovery - The Sorrow of War is not merely a story of firefights and military life. The story flits between those and his pre-Army life in Hanoi with Kien’s golden memories of his girlfriend Phuong and of life after the war where it is not only Kien who has been changed utterly but also Phuong, forever scarred by her travails when she accompanied him south to his first posting and her subsequent struggles to subsist in Hanoi.

The end of the war brought to the soldiers no soaring, brilliant happiness such as Kien saw later on film, only memories and nightmares. “Those who had died and those who lived on shared a common fate in this war.” As to the future, “Losses can be made good, damage can be repaired and wounds will heal in time. But the psychological scars of the war will remain forever.” The survivors “had lost not only the capacity to live happily with others but also the capacity to be in love.”

Since Kien later sets out to write about his impressions of the war the novel also contains observations on writing. Binh tells us the author wrote “because he had to write, not because he had to publish.” This is of course the way round the process ought to be.

Despite all its gruesome content and incident, its record of man’s inhumanity to man - and woman - The Sorrow of War is not difficult to read, a testament to both Binh and his translators.

Some books hit and hit hard. "Sorrow" hits hard not only because of the subject matter of the Vietnam War, but how it's written. It's a tremendously beautiful book, full of longing and nostalgic tremors. Ninh writes of a Vietnam that was, and a Vietnam that became. In some ways, "Sorrow" is meditative, a necessary exercise for the author to get rid of his demons. Bao Ninh was one of ten in a batallion of five hundred who survived. "Sorrow" is a testament of that survival.

It is easy to compare it to O'Brien's "The Things They Carried" - some of the stories of the Vietnamese jungle are eerily similar. For example, in "Things", O'Brien mentioned a mysterious symphony playing in the jungle, almost like an orchestra. Ninh mentioned music in the jungle too, haunting and melodious. I wonder if the marines in "Things" were listening to Vietnamese music.

"Sorrow" has no beginning and end. There is no suspense here. Kien, the narrator, described fairly early on how his comrades were going to die, in the battle for Saigon. The deaths of soldiers here, and the victims are never glorified, and always a waste. War gives the dead reprieve, and the survivors ghosts. There are no chapters either, the story (if you want to call it) flows from one paragraph to the next, without structure. And it works so well.

The book is about lost things. Time is divided into before and after the war, and so do the people. The mainstay of the book is Kien's childhood sweetheart, Phuong. She is a truly incredible character and the moments they spend together are absolutely gut-wrenching. As Kien described: "He had only two loves in his entire life. Phuong at seventeen in the pre-war days, and Phuong now, after the war." War and events like these changes people into two - divides them, damages them.

There are lost moments in the book that haunt him, perhaps haunts Ninh - hesitation in the battlefield, sexual tensions with girls, people who he'd never meet again. It is a book about memories. More than that - it is a book about writing. The book is borne from the author out of a necessity to write. As much as he wanted to burn his work at the end, I can understand why the author has that love and hate relationship with his work - the act of writing more important than what's written.

There are brutal moments too, of course. People forget themselves during wartime - they seem to switch to their base nature. Women become victims of violence, men fight each other over squabbles, corpses littered the jungles and backs of trucks, hammocks hanging above while the living sleeps above the dead. But there is much beauty in this brutality too. Kien's batallion found a woman's naked corpse and out of respect, dressed her before putting her with the rest of pile of corpses. It is an act of grace.

When I talk to people about this book, they tell me that it sounds depressing. Sure, it can be. But like any amazing books that blow you out of the water, you are left with a strange feeling of satisfaction. In some way, I'd like to think that Ninh found some reprieve by publishing this incredible book. (less)

Suddenly I feel like I understand why people like this book, even though I can't exactly explain why. May I just say "yes, now I can feel the sorrow of war, and for someone to be able to convey that deepest and vaguest of feeling to a stranger, it must have been one heck of a book"?

One thing I like about this book, and which explains (to me) why this is considered in the same league of (and not supplanted by) "All Quiet...", is that this is a different kind of wars. We'd think all wars are the same at its core, which is true. But each war also has its unique character. You go through a different setting, and feel a different way when you go through a war between equals, like in "All Quiet...". You go through a different kind of scenes and feelings when you're in a vastly imbalanced (in terms of material and killing power) war, like what the main character here had to go through. Good book for a serious, somewhat heavy read. (less)

The Vietnam War is a very difficult subject for me. Politically, horribly, divisively and invasively, it dominated my coming of age. I have read The Things They Carried by Tim O'Brien, which I thought excellent, but I could read no others. I tried to watch the PBS special but couldn't continue it. If you want to understand PTSD, this book shows its formation and strangle-hold better than any other. It is not an easy read for two reasons: one is the brutal subject matter. Science tells us it takes five minutes of war to irreparably change the brain. What would ten constant years do? The second is that it is not written in a chronological manner (neither was O'Brien's). The denouement is actually something that happens first, but you will not know that until the end. Brutal, heartbreaking and beautiful. Everyone should read this book. Given how the Vietnam War is always portrayed in pop culture from the point of view of heroic American soldiers, I can't stress enough on how important it is for people to read this book and get some perspective.

This is the second time I have read The Sorrow of War (1991) by Bao Ninh. In the Pham Ngu Lao area of Ho Chi Minh City I dined for lunch at La Cantina, a Mexican restaurant of sorts. One of the usual vendors came by carrying a stack of books. Having a beer at midday, I rummaged among the black market books. I came across an English translation of The Sorrow of War (1993) and opened it up. I began reading. Reading more as the woman placed her load on the table. What I read was sadness entire. What I read was beautiful. What I read was poetry and music. I purchased the black market copy for roughly $2 usd, and found a few of the pages out of order or missing. I finished the book any way. So after a year, (purchasing a valid copy this time from Amazon.com) I wanted to return to this story of innocent love and savage loss in times before, during, and after the Vietnam War.

Although The Sorrow of War is fiction, along the lines of A Farewell to Arms or All Quiet on the Western Front, it is a story of war told by a soldier. Bao Ninh served the North with the Glorious 27th Youth Brigade, and of over five hundred soldiers who went to war in 1969, Bao is one of only ten that survived.

The Sorrow of War tells of a young man, age 17, named Kien from Hanoi who falls in love with Phuong, a childhood sweetheart, and how war ultimately corrupts their love.

The novel is fragmented and pieced together. By the end of the novel the reader is told that Kien left the manuscript to a mute woman and vanished. A neighbor, a fellow soldier that remembers Kien, gets the pages and pieces the book back together and publishes the fragments as best he can. The story does jump around from postwar, prewar, and during war times, but the leaps and bounds only flow smoothly in to each other and helps shape the story of Kien and Phuong all the more.

Twenty years after the war, Kien sets out to write a novel. "Kien seems to write only to rid himself of his devils...He continues his quest for perfection, crossing out, erasing, crossing out again, editing, tearing up some pages, then tearing up and destroying all. Then he starts over again, making out each syllable like a learner trying to spell a new word" (pg. 49).

And Kien's story unfolds the horrors of a soul that has seen so much war:

"That autumn was sad, prolonged by rain. Orders came for food rations to be sharply reduced. Hungry, suffering successive bouts of malaria, the troops became anemic and their bodies broke in ulcers, showing through worn and torn clothing. They looked like lepers, not heroic forward scouts. Their faces looked moss-grown, hatched and sorrowful, without hope. It was a stinking life" (pg. 16).

"The uprush of so many souls penetrated Kien's mind, ate into his consciousness, becoming a dark shadow overhanging his own soul. Over a long period, over many, many graves, the souls of the beloved dead silently and gloomily dragged the sorrow of war into his life" (pg. 25).

"But war was a world with no home, no roof, no comforts. A miserable journey of endless drifting. War was a world without real men, without real women, without feeling. War was also a world without romance" (pg. 31).

"No. The ones who loved war were not the young men but the others like the politicians, middle-aged men with fat bellies and short legs. Not the ordinary people. The recent years of war had brought enough suffering and pain to last them a thousand years" (pg. 75).

"The sorrow of war inside a soldier's heart was in a strange way similar to the sorrow of love. It was a kind of nostalgia, like the immense sadness of a world at dusk. It was a sadness, a missing, a pain which could send one soaring back into the past. The sorrow of the battlefield could not normally be pinpointed to one particular event, or even one person. If you focused on any one event it would soon become a tearing pain" (pg. 94).

And there a several graphic scenes, like the one to follow, in this novel, a true novel of sorrow. The scene takes place on April 30, 1975, Victory Day, at Tan Son Nhat Airport near Saigon:

"Enraged, he grabbed the corpse by one leg and dragged her across the floor and down the stairs. Her skull thudded down the steps like a heavy ball. When he reached the concrete floor at the bottom of the stairs, he braced himself, lifted the dead girl, and threw her out into the sunshine next to the another pile of dead southern commandos. The body bounced up, her arms spread wide, and her mouth opened as if she was about to cry out. Her head dropped back with another thud on the concrete. The lout walked away jauntily, swinging his arms as if her were a hero" (pg. 102).


But there are also beautiful scenes that break one's heart when set next to the grief of war. This next scene reminds me a great deal about Vietnam; and when modernity finally comes to Vietnam and there are no more power outages, scenes like this will surely be missed:

"On summer evenings when there were power blackouts and it was too hot inside, everyone came to sit out in front, near the only water tap servicing the whole three-story building.

"The tap trickled, as drop by drop every story was told. Nothing remained secret. People said that Mrs. Thuy, the teacher widowed since her twenties, who was about to retire and become a grandmother, had suddenly fallen in love with Mr. Tu, the bookseller living on the corner of the same street. The two old people had tried to hide their love but had failed. It was true love, something that can't be easily hidden" (pg. 60-61).

The Sorrow of War is a tale of sorrow, lost loves, lost friends, and should be read knowing that not every book has a happy ending. A strong recommend.

Written from the perspective of a North Vietnamese soldier, this book explores the grief that lingered during and after the Vietnam War. It was really eye-opening to read about the psychological damage that affects Kien, the protagonist, and made it one of those reads that haunts you deeply.

Ninh's novel was very different than what I would normally choose to read. As I prepared to teach this for an IB english class, some descriptions of violence and abuse disturbed me. The Hanoi that I travelled to in 2018 carries the memories of this dark time in history. I'm glad that I finished it, and recommend this to anyone who's looking to read different perspectives on war. (less)

An important book that I was glad to have read. I didn't find the second half added much to my experience as a reader, but I can hardly complain since the book is a document of its time and never claimed to have the perfect plot arc. It wasn't written to win prizes. Similarly, if it were literary fiction then, sure, I'd have some complaints about the slightly naive way in which the narrator was placed at the centre and mediated everything through himself. But again this would be to hold it up against certain western literary expectations that don't apply here. The book didn't ask for for my Western viewpoint. Anyway, it was easy to skip through some parts and isn't a long book. It is what it is, and I'm glad I could read it. (less)

As I listened to the story I had to keep reminding myself that the author is relating this as a novel rather than the memoir, even if of a nation and not an individual, of a period of his nation's recent history. There are elements of any war of which we should all be aware before we send off the warfighter to prosecute that action, and that each and every action has the potential to change lives. There were a few phrases that sounded as though there really is no good English translation for some Vietnamese idioms, but the translator dealt with them as best could be done. Steps right up to the line of powerful literature.
(less)

I find the American depictions of the Vietnam War overwrought and overdone to the point where cliche bleeds into joke territory. I was surprised to find that this North Vietnamese depiction of the war followed so many of the tropes from the typical American perspective: the grotesque violence, the trippy toying with the reader's reality of narrative and narrator, the moral ambiguity, the pointlessness of it all, etc. The romance arc coupled with the nonlinear narrative is what really makes it stand out; it wasn't until that thread started picking up steam that I started getting into the story. (less)

I wonder if there can ever be a book, story about war and not be about the sorrow of war? Can anyone experience war in a way that does not have deep and personal consequences?
I had to stop reading a few times as I became confused and overwhelmed with the story-telling. I guess it was expected and aimed for given that it is all the sadness and confusion of the mind of a person whose life was lost to (a stupidly long and unnecessary) war.
In general hell of the war, the hero moves from memory to the other as the reader develops sympathy towards him: this is a young man whose life and growth broken by war. By the time we finally learn about his real cruelty we are knee-deep in his tragedy.
It is not wonderfully written but it does tell a story of sorrow. - hers. (less)

Whilst in Vietnam, having read O’Brien, I wanted to read a novel from the North Vietnamese perspective and this duly delivered. It is a challenging text, with a highly disjointed narrative style that requires focus and invites study. There are passages of beautiful descriptive prose, and there are others where translation has clearly impacted authenticity. For the first half of the novel, I had no real idea where the non-linear storytelling was going but the pieces come together powerfully in the final moments. Some of the imagery in this final section will, I imagine, stay with me for quite some time. (less)

Incredibly moving story told from an intriguing point of view. Listening to the audiobook reading of this, sometimes the timeline can become confusing, but regardless, a story that drags you in and stretches your heart.

As an American, we learn about the war in Vietnam much differently than it is portrayed here; this book humanizes "the enemy" and reminds me that in all wars, soldiers have families and loved ones and the scars of war last long after the last bullet flies.

Highly recommend this book to anyone, however, be prepared emotionally as this book can trigger some pretty strong feelings. (less)

This is the flip side of the same coin to The Things They Carried. I think this is an apt comparison and you can almost juxtapose one with the other as they both detail the absurdity, pain, loss, and ultimately the shattered lives of all those involved in the Vietnam war. The two books should be required reading for servicemen and women about to enter any war or conflict. We always consider the enemy, "the other", when in fact, our similarities far outnumber our differences. The real enemy is the state that sends innocent young men and women into needless and pointless wars in the name of.......what? I suppose you can fill in the blank.

(less)

3.8 - a disjointed novel that is sometimes difficult to follow in time and though a single protagonist (Kien) centers the majority of the story, there is an awkward first person and “writer” that sneak into the pages. The final 5 pages bring together the novel and provide a reason and purpose for the disjointed telling. But I needed more earlier. Yet, the powerful and deep theme of sorrow in many forms is well developed and carried. And after hundreds of books and movies from the American voice of this war, turning to the North Vietnamese voice makes this an essential read for those looking into that time...and a perspective of war in any time. (less)

An interesting novel from a Vietnam War veteran, a North Vietnamese veteran. It describes the war's effect on not just on combat soldiers, but on their families and close friends. One wonders how much is really fiction and how much might be biographical. The main character is a writer who is likely suffering from PTSD, not just from combat but from incidents occurring prior to combat. The act of writing is cathartic as he describes incidents which are possible causes of his PTSD. It is a book people should read to understand how war affects people. (less)

War is not romantic. Soldiers are not always brave. Win or lose, war leaves painful scars in the lives of many. History generally records the leading events, events during the war, personalities involved in the war etc but seldom talks about the aftermath and the impact of it on the lives of people. This book records such events. Most accounts are heartrending and makes you think what was it all about. Who gained from the war if almost everyone involved in it directly or indirectly feels so much grief and pain? (less)

Interesting to hear the view from the Vietnamese side, and I appreciated that it was very balanced, and not trying to be heroic, i.e. it didn't just cover combat and slaughter, but also the lives and thoughts of vietnamese people trying to get by during the war. I had expected a lot of vitriol against the occupying American forces, but they are barely mentioned by name and kind of just treated as a part of a chaotic mess that the vietnamese have gotten used to.

The writing, however, is just average, a bit too old- fashioned for my taste, and gets quite sentimental in the end. (less)

this is the story of an NVA soldier coming down to the south in Vietnam to fight for what his country told him was honor. The stark realities of war are the same for both sides. Harsh living conditions , battle field chaos...wounded and dying ......and lots of helicopters . I like seeing what life was like for the soldiers there at the same time I was there. Bao Ninh was born in 1952, the same year as myself, I was over in Nam in 1972 , as a Medic....the story in his book is in 1971.

Oddly similar to a book that I recently read, VS Naipaul's 'The Enigma of Arrival'. Same type of structure and introspection regarding a writer's struggle to create.

Wish the book had told Phuong's story.

Well worth reading.

Find it somewhat surprising that the Vietnamese govt allowed the book's publication. That is a good thing regardless of the book's literary merit...and the book has all of that.

The translation seemed, for the most part, well done - always have to wonder though, how true to Bao Ninh's novel the translation actually was. (less)

It's a little disjointed, a little trite, but at the same time you can't fault the heart that lies within this story - it's obvious he wants to tell us something, wants to tell us about the horror of the war, and the passages that cover the death and destruction and futility of war really bring that home. The passages which attempt to join them up (after the war, the idea of the 'writer', the way the book ends) is not so good. But still full of sincerity and raw emotion, which must not be underestimated. (less)

3.5 stars. Told by a North Vietnamese combatant, The Sorrow of War reminds its English readers the hells of war know no political boundaries. It irrevocably scars and reshapes persons, families, and communities. Here are devastating accounts of innocence lost and dreams vanquished. The book is not consumed with military tactics or battlefield skirmishes. Most of the tension involves the dissolution of youthful love downstream from the catastrophes of combat. Be warned the content is often sexually graphic, and that tempers my willingness to recommend it for broad consumption. (less)

Really haunting book. The language is beautiful, not sure how closely the translation is to the original in Vietnamese. Enough brutality, from both sides, to last an eternity. I've been trying to better understand the Vietnamese War, but it's not as simple as that - you have to also understand French colonialism (and English colonialism, and Dutch colonialism, and Spanish colonialism, and...). Each of the characters in the book was (were) horribly damaged; I wish there were no wars, so no war books.
(less)

The Vietnam War...the disillusion of a young couple in the brutality they encounter.
It's not a straightforward narrative...there are disjointed first person accounts of events experienced, then later accounts of their author- middle aged, a writer and a rather lost soul, still defined by the War, working on his memoir...and finally Bao Ninh himself (one assumes), crafting a narrative from the random pages he's acquired...

I can't say it hugely grabbed me , though it's an important account of a hideous time. (less)

The Sorrow of War is a powerful story of the Vietnam War and the tragic consequences it had for those who fought and survived it and who were forever haunted by it’s memory.

A thought provoking tale of the horrors of war and the shattered lives that struggle for meaning and purpose in its aftermath. Countless lives lost, enormous human sacrifice, dreams shattered, unimaginable horrors witnessed, the callous indifference that war breeds and the lasting psychological trauma it creates are all core elements of this well crafted novel. (less)

I've recently moved to HCMC and having visited the War Memorial Museum and learned a lot about the war since moving here, I thought this is the one book I should read to really understand it.

This was a very sorrow book to read and was actually quite difficult to read considering I'm in a happy state of mind. I was going to give it four stars until the last 30 pages of the way Kien treated Phuong and how her character was portrayed. (less)

This is not any easy read, from an emotional nor experiential standpoint. To be able to glimpse at the Vietnam War through the North Vietnamese soldier's life was, for me, unexpected. The author brings the experience to life slowly using language that seems to paint a picture, not send a snapshot. I was a child during this war, raised on the sounds of it through the evening news. This book helps to understand the human experience in that time and place. (less)

This book is like a stream of consciousness and even though it bounces around, you always know what is going on. It is incredibly heartbreaking and makes the reader feel like they are experiencing each moment. For example, I was reading on my balcony during the scene where the train was bombed. I could bear construction noises that made me think subconsciously that I was actually hearing the war going on.

The Sorrow of War demonstrates the horrors of war from the perspective of a young soldier named Kien whose life after the Fall of Saigon was shaped by the memories of his experiences in the field as he searches for fallen comrades in the Vietnamese jungle.

Semi-autobiographical, it leads the reader to question the justification of war in general and how the individual who has to live with the trauma of having lived when so many died.

A must read if you are interested in the Vietnam War. It is a searing description of what the title says: the sorrow of war, and like all great war literature, achieves universality. I read it after hearing the author interviewed on Ken Burns's multi-part documentary, and on the recommendation of Viet Than Nguyen, the author of The Sympathizer. It was hard going for the first third or so, but I'm glad I persisted. (less)

Despite the story being somewhat raw in terms of graphic descriptions of the Vietnam war (and the sorrow of it all), it flowed beautifully. I found reading the story of that war from the North Vietnam soldier’s perspective refreshing and enlightening. For me, the book was thought provoking as well as emotion provoking. The characters and the sadness and the hope stuck with me even after I finished the book.

During the first 50 or so pages of the novel, the writing style is a bit bemusing, but the narrative becomes much more engaging following this rough patch. The novel's theme of forcing your consciousness back into battle although the war has been long over can be related in the works of Tim O'Brien, an author I thoroughly enjoy. Altogether a good starting point for anyone who wants to read from the perspective of the Vietnamese during the war years. (less)

I was very moved by this book. Extremely well written and easy to follow. The book uses stream of consciousness writing similar to the style of Slaughterhouse 5 jumping around to different points in the main characters life. By the end all the characters were finally teased out, the story made sense, and was very thought provoking.

I would definitely read it again, although it is a very sad story.

This book felt like a collection of randomly arranged short stories, so it was a lot of start-stop-start for me. I'd forget characters and couldn't follow the plot. Still, each segment was told wonderfully, effectively conveying the horrors and sorrow of Vietnam War. I like that it didn't have a hero and glorify any side (US or Vietnam). It was consistent with its message - only violence, fear, and sorrow win in war. (less)

It was very interesting learning about the Vietnam War from the point of view of the Vietnamese as often their voices are underrepresented and heard less with American interpretations of the war stealing most of the attention despite not being in the war the whole time.
It was a very emotional but in a good way book.
I would thoroughly recommend it for anyone wanting to learn more about the shocking and disastrous effects of war as this book demonstrates it so well.

Despite the poetry and many insightful commentaries, the novel suffers from the one-man syndrome, meaning that the viewpoint of a single man is simply not compatible with the total nature of war. We have the viewpoint of his past lover as well, of course, but I'd have prefered that other accounts came in to paint a more diverse picture. The last forceful act of humanism from the first person writer of the novel is also extremely problematic. (less)

Chaotic, heartfelt, totally atmospheric: Bao Ninh’s emotionally raw treatise on war and the sorrow it leaves in the lives of its survivors is less a story of combat and hardship than it is one broken man’s perspective on how life changes you, how the past can so jarringly differ from the present, and how people grow apart or together due to the trauma they’ve endured. It is a calm and pensive reflection; it is peace in sorrow.

Not quite 3 stars but certainly not 2 stars. I felt like I was facing something great but somehow didn't really click with it. Beautifully written though. The structure was kind of confusing, jumping around from different points in the past to present, etc which took some getting used to. The novel is more like anecdotes that slowly became more connected and finally told the story of a veteran from the Vietnam War. (less)

If you are at all curious of the brutal and uninspiring reality of the Vietnam war, look no further. Although the title of this book denotes a depressing meaning, there is wisdom and inspiration to be taken from this. This novel also shows what the Vietnam war was like from the Vietnamese perspective, which is something that was totally new to me. Expect an expansion in your perspective if you read this book!

The Sorrow of War is the narrative of Kien, a North Vietnamese soldier, and his time time before, during, and after the Vietnam War. He recalls memories of these times in a stream of consciousness style which fits well with the content and messages of the novel but does make it more challenging for the reader. The novel is filled with heart-wrenching moments which are exquisitely rendered; Ninh ensures his readers see and feel the sorrow of war.

I became aware of Bao Ninh while watching Ken Burns series about the War in Viet Nam and with that introduction sought out what he had written. This is an incredible book which tells the story of those who were sent by their country, not unlike American troops, into a war not of their choosing and in his telling the story of a soldier named Kien, we are told of the horrors of war and indeed the sorrow of war. This is a hard but at the same time an amazing read.

Technically historical fiction, this book invites us on a walk down memory lane with a former North Vietnamese soldier. Aptly titled, the stories-a compilation of those heard by the author-bring one into the destruction caused by war. The brilliance of this novel lies in its ability to not just share stories, but bring the reader into a world of despair and sorrow--an experience unlikely to be forgotten.

This is a novel that seems to have a lot of the writer's personal experience. Sad and honest this is about life's s worst moments and the willingness and strength that keep people alive. Mind and heart travel in time to find the sweet spots that feed the soul and keep the body alive in a narrative that is fast and deep a the same time. (less)

This is a powerful, beautifully written novel. To go from its original Vietnamese through and English translation and retain its fluid delivery is remarkable. Credit to author and translator. The story follows a North Vietnamese infantry scout who fights in war for 10 years from '65 to '75. It is not about war as much as surrounded by war. (less)

A series of tragic love stories, youths lost to horrible, gruesome fighting, and then everyone dies or goes insane in the end. Super depressing. War sucks and nobody wins. I had hoped there would be more historical background but enjoyed the little bits that were there, as well as the descriptions of Hanoi, the central highlands, etc nevertheless. Vietnam is an amazing country.

It was slow to get going for me, starting with the ghosts of the missing and dead at the end of the war, then peeling off layers of the author's wartime, prewar and postwar life. There is not a narrative flow but a series of narratives taking you deeper into the story. By the end you know the story and have witnessed the many sorrows of war, and after the war, of the people who were in it. (less)

I rarely read a sad story or a wonderfully written story with a sad ending?! But I couldn't put this book down.
The story of the war is told with an indescribable sadness floating in the air. The author is a world class writer who are able to make a reader to be extremely emotional just by words. Hat off.
Obsession.Sorrow.Flashbacks. (less)

I really wanted to like this book but it was hard. It is less a novel than a stream of consciousness spilling of details. It is not particularly in chronological order which complicates the reading. There really was not a plot, very little happened and there was no resolution at all. It was good to "see" the war from the other side, however disjointed it was presented. (less)

Painfully Intense. Surely one of the most deeply moving books I have ever read. Initially, the odd language of the translation bothered me, but before long, I realized that it beautifully enhanced the characters and entire narrative: the protagonist, Kien, never paused a second in his “Vietnamese-ness”. and the story never became “Westernised”. It just worked — the unusual choice of words and comparisons actually made Kien a more genuine and complete individual. This is a heart-wrenching story that made me realize how fortunate I am to even be reading it and how very grateful I am for never actually experiencing such profound sorrow, although the author seems to write your soul into the lives of his characters making you feel as though you have. (less)

There is always light at the end of the tunnel - it doesn't matter if the direction of the tunnel is towards the past or the future. The chapters are scattered just as the hearts of all of the people who have lived the war. This novel is more powerful than any movies or photographs of the war that I have seen. I highly recommend this book, particularly to politicians! (less)

The parts about the war were very saddening and very well written. I didn't enjoy the way the main character treated his female companion and the way she was written and described at certain points made me want to scream. The main character was very selfish but I don't think the author intended on him being perceived that way. Either way eye opening perspective from the other side of the war. (less)

From start to finish, the plot of this book is spellbinding, fluid, and exotic. As an American, I especially was riveted to the accounts of the war experiences from the North Vietnamese perspective because it gave me a more balanced understanding of the poignancy of the book’s title. I wholeheartedly recommend this book from the pen of a master story teller . . .

I read this book when I was traveling in Vietnam. At the time, the writing swept me off my feet and transported me away from hot and dusty HCMC to northern jungles that hung with cold mists and that were perfumed with the scent of delirium-inducing white flowers.
Looking back on it though, I recall one too many luridly described rape scenes.

Spectacularly moving, deeply troubling... I feel like this book is an important counterpart to American literature of the Vietnam War, like Tim O'Brien's The Things They Carried. This is a must-read for those who are seeking a more comprehensive cultural, political and ethical understanding of war and its effect on the human condition. I'm extremely grateful to have encountered The Sorrow of War. (less)

An intimate depiction of war and the way it can devastate a country and people not just physically but psychologically. The sorrow of the war the Bao Ninh and his compatriots endured and live with permeates every page of the book. It also provides an unvarnished and authentic North Vietnamese perspective on the war. I think Americans like myself greatly benefit from reading this book.

This book was a struggle for me. I would have abandoned if it hadn’t been a book club read. It was scattered for a good portion of the book. It makes sense for the story but made it really hard to get into. This book pushed me as a reader. I just can’t believe how hard it was to finish a book that was around 200 pages.

I found that the first half of the book was quite lose, as it jumped back and forth on time, retelling different stories with many different characters, but without really following a storyline . It didn’t really grab my attention properly until I started reading the second half, at which point the book was starting to become difficult to put down. Sad story showing the impact of war on people.

I loved this book...sad, brutal, but really touching and compelling, too...for me, the Vietnam War took place from age four to age fourteen, and it was a big part of my and most other people's lives in America at that time...to see it from the other side was both sad and gratifying...highly recommended! (less)

Although it is a fictional novel, I personally find The Sorrow of War more of a memoir. And I don't like reading memoirs, sadly. It's not... well structured, it's too confusing between memory and reality. I'm not sure what the author meant here, but I feel that if he rearranged the flow of the story a bit, the book would be much better. (less)

Visceral, detailed and exceptionally sad collection of tales on the Vietnam War. It was so detailed that I couldn't actually finish the book. That said, this is the type of book that should be part of a required reading list before deciding to go to war. (less)

Relentless heartbreak. Disconnected manic anecdotes of extreme suffering and disillusionment build on each other to reveal Kien's source of sorrow in a horrific climax. A viewpoint of the Vietnam War rarely heard from. Ninh questions everything that was fought for by the Northern Vietnamese. (less)

For me, The Sorrow of War started off unremarkably and improved as the book progressed. The whole book struck me as a little overdone, but that style of writing seems to be present in the few translated Vietnamese books I've read and doesn't always undermine it. The most compelling part of the book was the destroyed love between the main character and his childhood / teenage love. This aspect of the somewhat scattered story kept me engaged enough to keep coming back to the book. (less)

This book is so beautifully written. It’s Eerily similar to The Thjngs They Carried. Begs the question: is there really a “winner” in war? Really puts a human face on an “enemy” that is routinely demonized.

Sad but compelling. Vietnam won the war but at such a cost. Remember, for the Vietnamese this was The American War, a dreadful continuation of a war of independence that had stretched back into the 1940's and the end of WWII. So many devastated generations. (less)

My son gave me this at Christmas. I read about half way but was not finding it: 1. easy to read and 2. having any new information from the several books listed that I read prior to visiting listed that I would recommend much more.

Horrific, compelling account of Vietnam war - from Vietnamese pov.
Shifts back and forth in time, as narrator recalls, recounts and tries to recover from his experience by writing.
I'm so lucky I've never yet been involved in anything like this. A war that tears everything apart. (less)

Bao Ninh is one of the North Vietnamese soldiers interviewed extensively in the PBS documentary, The Vietnam War. He's the one with the bleached hair. The book is heartbreaking and excellent. It reminded me of "The Things They Carried". Very highly recommended. (less)

Not a easy book to read. The author writing style is poetic and poignant but also heart wrenching in its accounts of the trauma of war. Indeed, for war, no one is a winner. The harsh realities will be marred in your mind upon reading it.

Great book
Bao Ninh somekind of unable to handle the chaos of the story. He brings out the sorrow but cannot develop further.

A moving story of love and war, loss and grief, told by a soldier fighting for North Vietnam. Translated into English, this is an emotional story that adds another prospective to this terrible conflict.

I respect the struggles the author had in getting this published, but as far as someone reading this in the year 2020 this doesn't really tread any new ground - the themes and ideas you'll read in this are the same you've probably heard everywhere else, and probably using fewer cliches. (less)

The vivid description of nature and battle fields is exceptional and thus haunting. On the other hand, this is such a depressing and hopeless book. I remember having a miserable time reading through it.

Powerful depictions of war presented by a key interviewee from the Netflix series. While the love struggle manages to mirror the absurdities of the era, there is something that seems lacking in delivery - leaving you yearning for more poignancy. 3.5/5

This was an okay book. It is written from the perspective of a North Vietnam Soldier, which was interesting. It was, however, very disjointed and hard to follow at times. It is a recommended read for those wanting to read more about Vietnam.

This is possibly one of the best novels of the Vietnam War that I’ve ever read. Sublime and piercing, Bao Ninh offers a lucid perspective on the horrors of the war from a North Vietnamese perspective.

Very moving

This is a very moving, very good book about a difficult time and a difficult life. It is sometimes confusing because there are no chapters and the time frame changes without warning. But it makes you think.

A powerful war book.

Dear prospective readers, be prepared for emotional work necessary for reading books of this kind, containing pages after pages of sadness,and sadness after sadness 🧎. I’m surprised the book is not more popular. The translation is excellent .

Gorgeous writing. It's not often that we get to read about the other side of war and in this case, I think it's important that people understand what happened to all sides during the Vietnam War. A hard read. (less)

Incredibly powerful. Very well written.

Excellent. Very hard to get through some times. An intense reminder that war is hell and everyone feels the repercussions.

5 stars because of the haphazard chronology that kinda makes sense.
Wowzas in me trousas. This is a good one. It is not happy by any means, but a great book to read while backpacking around Vietnam. A lot of feeling here.

Is the life of victors of the war full of roses?

Best Vietnamese book about war and lost love. Highly recommend!
Beautiful and simple, but not forgettable.

Fantastic novel, depressing at times. Elucidates the horrors of war.

At times brutal, at times tender, this is a remarkable book. Told from the viewpoint of a North Vietnamese soldier in the middle of a terrible, brutal war, it is a novel within a novel.

a perspective you won’t get from the majority of books about the war in vietnam. full of brutal and impactful imagery.

audiobook. Ot expanded my horizons and increased my appreciation for vietnamese culture

Touching :)
Read this one by mistake, thought it was non fiction when purchased. Worth a read if you’re okay with some make believe weaved into what life was like as a North Vietnam solder.

Amazing book

This book is an excellent look at war .I highly recommend this book.

One of the very few books written from the perspective of Vietnamese army on the Vietnam was on which there are thousands of accounts of American heroism!
