Thu Huong Duong is one of Vietnam’s most celebrated writers but also a controversial one because of her criticism of the Communist party. In « Les paradis aveugles », she follows the life of a young Vietnamese lady who struggles with her individuality in an environnement where family obligations and also oppressive communist inspired policies prevail.

I enjoyed her descriptions of the people and landscapes of Vietnam, she writes in a very poetic and visual way. She particularly rendered the life of the street vendors in a vivid way. She also brilliantly tackled the errors of the Communist government in the newly independent country of Vietnam (bad land reform, humiliations of certain people, corruption) and the frustration of the youth born after the wars.

Her quest to live a fulfilling life while maintaining good ties with her family was touching and certainly a universal theme that could interest all readers, whether or not they want to learn about Vietnam. (less)
Readers of translated literature.

Like most dissident writers, Duong Thu Huong spends a lot of time on the day-to-day pettiness and miseries of the new regime. And yet it doesn't read as a political diatribe at all, largely thanks to the lyrical writing – elegant depictions of landscape and the scents of food set the tenor for the book rather than the humiliations and setbacks of the characters. And Hang, the focal point of the story, is a remarkable character, as she tries, simply, to make her own way amid the back alleys of Hanoi, and then in the grim dormitories of the USSR in the dark, leaden Brezhnev-Andropov years. Really, it has more in common with an old '50s existentialist novel than any of the normal range of exile and dissident literature (the Solzhenitsyns, the Bulgakovs, etc.). Read this alongside Duong's Novel Without a Name-- that one for the large-scale scope, this one for the intimacies. (less)

Paradise of the Blind, by Vietnamese novelist Duong Thu Huong, was first published in Vietnam in 1988 and translated into English in 1993. It was the first novel from Vietnam ever published in the United States and gave American readers authentic insight into the poverty and political corruption that characterized Vietnam under the communist government from the 1950s to the 1980s. Although to most Americans the name Vietnam conjures up images of the Vietnam War, the novel does not concern itself with what the Vietnamese call the American War. It begins in Russia in the 1980s, as Hang, a young Vietnamese woman, travels to Moscow to visit her uncle. As she travels, she recalls incidents from her childhood and adolescence in Hanoi and also tells of life in her mother's village during the communists' disastrous land reform program that took place in the mid-1950s. The novel, which was banned in Vietnam, is essentially the story of three women from two generations whose family is torn apart by a brother who insists on placing communist ideology above family loyalty. The exotic setting and descriptions of the lives of ordinary Vietnamese people in rural and urban areas, combined with the story of young Hang's struggle to forge her own path in life, make for a compelling story.

What sets in motion the multiple individual tragedies of the novel is the attempt by the victorious communists to impose the principles of Marxism on their society. According to Marxism, in every society there is a struggle between the exploiters, the landowners or factory owners (the bourgeoisie), and the exploited, the peasants and the working classes. The so-called land reform that the communists enact in the novel is a catastrophic failure and causes great injustice, "sowing only chaos and misery in its wake," as far as Que's village is concerned. In the village, anyone who owns even a tiny amount of land is declared to be an enemy of the peasantry, even though these small landowners have never exploited anyone. Nonetheless, their property is arbitrarily seized on the orders of Que's brother, Chinh, who thinks only in terms of rigid Marxist theory of class struggle. It is Chinh's adherence to this theory that creates and perpetuates injustice in his own family. Putting ideology above family, he denounces Ton, his own brother-in-law, for the simple reason that Ton's family hired farm labor and, therefore, belong to the exploiting class. Chinh's ideological zeal leads to Ton's exile and death; Que's unhappiness; the lifetime enmity of Ton's sister, Tam; and Hang's loneliness as she grows up without a father.

In addition to applying Marxist theories in a rigid, uniform manner regardless of local conditions or common sense, the Communist Party depicted in the novel is also corrupt. Chinh and his Party hacks use official visits to Russia to make money by trading luxury goods on the black market. The hypocrisy of this is apparent in Moscow when Chinh, who must be well aware of what is going on, hectors his colleagues, telling them they "must behave in an absolutely exemplary manner while you are in this brother country." Not only this, Chinh enriches himself with the perks available to government officials. He owns a new Japanese television set and refuses to sell it even to help raise money for his sister Que, who has just had her leg amputated.

There is also the corruption of Duong, the vice president of Aunt Tam's village, who seizes land to which he has no right. The most savage indictment of hypocrisy of the communist rulers comes from the student Hang refers to as the Bohemian, who harangues Chinh in Khoa's Moscow apartment: "They decreed their thousands of rules, their innumerable edicts, each one more draconian than the last. But, in the shadows, they paddled around in the mud, without faith or law." The Bohemian asserts that what all the Party officials really sought was not the good of the country but power and perks for themselves. Indeed, this is the thread that runs through Chinh's life. For example, he claims to be concerned with his sister's welfare, but the real reason he gets her a job in a factory is that he thinks having a street vendor for a sister is harming his own chances of advancement in the Party. It is ironic that Chinh lectures his sister about putting the interests of her own class above her self-interests, when he himself, under the guise of ideological purity, does the opposite.

The devastation brought about by the land reform, which results in the persecution and eventual death of Hang's father Ton, is that Hang grows up with deep feelings of loneliness, and two families are permanently divided. Mocked by her neighbors for being the fatherless child, Hang looks back on her childhood, seeing it "like a ball kicked across the road, aimless, without any purpose." She lacks any sense of self-worth, a consequence of growing up without a name, not knowing who her father was. She compares herself to "an anonymous weed [that] grows between the cracks of a wall" and also feels a long-lasting sense of humiliation and injustice about her life. One night she dreams she is being beaten, and this feeling of senseless oppression stays with her as she matures. She feels shame at having to associate with her uncle, who has been the cause of such distress to the family. When she visits him in Moscow she refers to her life as "this slow torture, this bottomless sadness." When she is twenty she refers to the "dark circles of misery" she sees under her eyes when she looks in the mirror, and she sees the same unhappiness in an entire generation of young Vietnamese, who see no future for themselves in their society.

The narrator creates a reflective, often sad atmosphere through her poetic descriptions of the landscapes she remembers, both in Vietnam and Russia. She emphasizes the emotional effects these landscapes had on her. One example occurs in chapter 5, when she describes the first snowfall she ever witnessed, in Russia. The beauty of it "pierced my soul like sorrow." This thought prompts her to recall a moment when she was a girl and her mother had taken her to visit a beach; the beauty of the scene at dawn was so extreme it was painful to Hang, perhaps because it was such a contrast to the reality of her impoverished and insecure life.

Particularly evocative are the descriptions of the slum in Hanoi where Hang grew up. She recreates the sights, smells, sounds of her childhood in all their sensory details: the brick hut in which she lived, with its leaky roof; the sounds of the street vendors as they set up their stalls in the morning and their characteristics cries as they hawk their wares; the voice of the crippled man who always sings the same mournful song; the sounds and smells of many families cooking. There are numerous descriptions of food in the novel; food is important to Hang because in her childhood she sometimes goes hungry, and even at the best of times her diet lacks variety. On occasions, too, her mother gets sick because of lack of adequate food. Therefore, as Hang grows up she always notices and records in great detail occasions when food is present in abundance and variety, such as the feasts put on by Aunt Tam. Such occasions, suggesting the resilience and goodness of life, act as a counterweight to the adversity that in general characterizes the lives of the Vietnamese people.

The Paradise of the Blind depicts both the beauty and oppression of life permeated by culture and ideology and shows in its hopeful ending that it is possible for determined individuals to resist and transcend these powerful forces. (less)

I would call Paradise of the Blind a powerful feminist novel simply for the fact that it’s an authentically told story of women. It mostly focuses on Hang and her relationship with her mother and Aunt Tam. Those relationships are complex. Nothing brings more pain to Hang’s life than her mother, but giving up on a mother who brings you pain is nearly impossible. At the same time, she loves Aunt Tam more than anything, but there's a certain amount of pain that comes with that.

There are several male characters that are equally as important to her life. She even has a character that may or may not turn into a love interest. The great thing about this story is that you don't want to focus on those relationships. You just want to focus on the women. And in the end, Hang's relationships with her mother and aunt are the only ones which are tied up nicely. All the other relationships are left open-ended. (I don't think that's much of a spoiler.)

As much as the powerful message, I loved the whole aesthetic of the story. The entire narrative unfolds naturally. By the time Hang voices how she’s feeling about anything, you’re already feeling it too because you’ve gone through it with her.

The story takes place in Vietnam and Russia. I’ve never been to either, but I could almost feel the air and the energy of whatever setting was presented. The language was poetic but informative. Absolutely gorgeous. While reading, I highlighted several lines throughout the book because they were so beautifully written. I read this twice back to back because I just wanted to live in it. Highly recommend. (less)

Seeing the mistakes of the communist government in their Maoist style land reforms as told by the regular every day people was enlightening.

The characters are interesting and you can really see how macro politics can have such a devastating effect on others on the ground.

Some of the absurdity was funny and I thought that although the book started slow it got better as it went on.

Raised in the slums of postwar Vietnam, Hang has lived a simple and hard life with her mother, who runs a tiny stall at a street market. While they find comfort in each other while Hang is young, the past slowly encroaches on them and Hang ends up in the center of a fierce feud between her mother and the sister of her father. Jealousy, family strife and her mother's strange way of satisfying her own need to be needed create havoc for Hang.

When I was trying to tell my husband about this novel, I was struck by the despair, the constant struggle of the Vietnamese peasants, both in the slums and in tiny remote villages. Events between the Communists and the people of Huang's mother's village would change all their lives forever - and everyone is searching for someone to blame. Huong's writing is so haunting, so precise, and it's very clear that she is writing from the perspective of one who has suffered at the hands of the communist party in Vietnam. I can see why this book was banned there - I would imagine that her portrayal of local Communist leaders is not the sort that would bring a government much pleasure.

I enjoyed this book for the flavors and smells - the rich picture it painted of a culture I knew virtually nothing about. It's politically charged, to be sure, and old and new ways often struggled to coexist. The narrative style made it a slow read for me, though, it jumped back and forth in time a lot. I think it could have been put together in a way that was easier for the reader, but I wonder if part of that is just a cultural preference. Read this book for a true sense of life in a Vietnam of not-so-long-ago, and brace yourself for a bitter but beautiful road. (less)

The Long-Suffering Wife (LSW) got a copy of this book after reading The Beauty of Humanity Movement by Camilla Gibb, who cited this book as an inspiration for her novel. LSW then read and loved it.

We North Americans (Gibb is Canadian) tend to bring a certain sunny optimism to all topics, motivated at least in part by the knowledge that, of the ever-shrinking pool of people who read, many feel their lives are sufficiently difficult without reading books that throw the less pleasant parts of life into higher relief. This novel was written by a Vietnamese (and later banned in Vietnam). Although I managed to live in Vietnam for two years without really understanding its inhabitants, I learned through hard experience that sunny optimism is never the default position for Vietnamese, so I was prepared for a readable and well-translated slog through needless suffering, spiteful family relationships, the relentless quest for material success (the only yardstick to measure one's worth both in this life and the next), and the constant rendering of loud and obvious judgment on everyone else one meets. That's what I got.

In short, not the sort of novel to take the edges off after a hard day in the cubicle, but still an accurate representation of a time (early 1980's) and place that were not known to many in the West at the time and are now receding into memory. If you are not reading books (at least sometimes) to know things like that, well, then, don't come sit by me. (less)

I do not understand why this book was chosen to be in "1001 Books You Must Read Before You Die." Yes, the descriptions of the food and countryside are beautiful. Paradise of the Blind is a Vietnamese novel which was apparently a bestseller in 1988 when it was originally published, in a relatively liberal moment in that country’s recent politics, but has since been banned for Duong’s unflattering portrayal of the Communist party. I’m embarrassed to admit, I had no idea that Vietnam was still a communist state. In fact, most of my associations with Vietnam are, now I think about it, drawn entirely from American war movies. So if nothing else, this book has done a little to redress that balance.

It is told mainly in flashback; Hang, a young Vietnamese woman working in a textile factory in the Soviet Union as an ‘exported worker’, is travelling across Russia on the train to visit her uncle in Moscow and remembering her childhood. Her family has been torn apart by communist land reforms, or more precisely by a feud resulting from her uncle’s behaviour as a party official during those reforms.

I’ve mentioned before that I find these novels from communist countries weirdly nostalgic. It’s not nostalgia for communism itself, which I didn’t experience. But all the imagery of communism, the breadlines, dysfunctional communal living, petty bureaucracy, the political jargon, the dangerous black market consumer goods, it all reminds me of my childhood, when the USSR was still the Great Other, and when all these images were a lively strand of popular culture. It seems a little odd to lump communism in with Smash Hits and The Karate Kid, but that’s the way my head works.

My own quirks aside, it’s a striking and interesting novel about family relationships, and Vietnamese culture, and above all, the way that an all-consuming, inhuman political system drags down the daily lives of its citizens, and capriciously interferes with the most modest, simple human ambitions: marriage, education, livelihood.

It’s not what you’d call a cheerful book. But I would broadly recommend it.

Her commentary and insights into communist Vietnam and Vietnamese family and community dynamics are interesting, and there is much to be said about the fact that it was banned, but overall this is not a thrilling read. This is a story of a young Vietnamese woman growing up in Vietnam during communism. Part of the story takes place in Soviet Russia. There are no references to specific years or specific political events, but we suspect that the protagonist meets her uncle in Russia in the late Brezhnev or early Andropov era. A brief mention of the Vietnamese-Chinese war suggests the 80's. The novel documents the disillusionment with the failed communist experiment in Vietnam. This disillusionment seems to have happened across all social classes. There is no mention of the USA anywhere, and barely any discussion of the civil war. It's clear that much of what's described comes from personal experience - including the juicy Bulgarian peach sold on a Russian train station. Interestingly, the name of Alla Pugatchova (the legendary Soviet pop music icon) was changed to Pugatnova - I wonder why, was it a slip by the editor?

Duong Thu Huong's "Paradise of the Blind" was the first Vietnamese novel ever published in the United States. Huong's work was banned in her own country due to its political content and she has been imprisoned there as well.

That doesn't mean the novel is simply a political statement. In fact, it feels more like a personal story. The novel tells the story of Hang, a worker who is forced into "exported labor" in Russia. She travels by train to visit a hated uncle, and reminisces about her family's story. Communism's impact is thread running through her family's struggle to survive.

The Communist party of North Vietnam in the 20th century destroyed families and disrupted whole communities. In the 1950s, anybody who had a house, any land, the smallest noodle shack, was denounced and forced to give up all their possessions, and shunned and shamed. Madame Que, the protagonist's mother, us married to a teacher, who is denounced. Hang's father leaves the village, and we never see him again. In fact, you will miss Hang's conception if you're not paying attention. Hang's Aunt Tam, her father's sister, maintains a lifelong love, defence, and reverence for him, and hates Madame Que for not keeping his memory alive for Hang. Madame Que, on the other hand, reveres her brother, a minor official in the Communist party, and the instigator of the denouncements of Hang's father and sister, and the consequent destruction of their lives. But Aunt Tam, really the central character, works her fingers to the Bone and rebuilds her life, while the petty Communist official lives a life of deprivation and hypocrisy. Hang is denied a father, and has a troubled relationship with her mother, which eventually totally crumbles. This book is a chronicle of what beauty, energy, spirit, and inspiration lies in the Earth, and how Humans can miss the whole beauty and happiness this life offers them, believing that happiness lies in material success, the esteem of whatever group is currently in power, and false pride.

One of the reasons why I really love historical novels, or historical fiction in general, is that I feel that I learn more about the places and people than just reading a history book. There is something more personal. Even the greatest history books won’t succeed if it’s just narration of one fact after another. This is why I loved this novel by the Vietnamese author Duong Thu Huong. When most outsiders, including myself I admit, hear the name “Vietnam”, the first images that come to our minds are of the war, and not the war from the Vietnamese perspective, in most cases. Heck, even if you search “Vietnamese music” on Youtube, some of the first results you’ll get are the Rock songs during the 60s and 70s that are associated with Vietnam through foreign culture. This is why the novel explores to different periods of modern Vietnamese history, the Vietnamese land reforms during the 50s which took place against the fall of French colonialism, and the post war period in the 80s. We learn how people had to scramble to survive at times, and just do their best to live during harsh times. Many people praise it as an “anti-communist” novel or a critique of socialism. This isn’t my impression. The novel’s framework is about how governments can roll over their people with their “projects”. It’s entirely told through the eyes of its people as brutal changes are forced upon them, and how society evolves with these changes. Yet at the heart of this novel, we have three crucial figures, three women: A daughter, a mother, and an aunt.

This is above all a family drama. Chang, a young woman and the narrator of the novel, was forced to leave her studies to work as a textile. She lives in Russia as an “exported worker” and is urgently summoned by her uncle Chinh, an official in the communist party living in Moscow. She narrates to us her harsh childhood through on her train voyage as we discover more and more the family drama. Chang’s mother Que is a proud woman and cherishes her family above all, and would sacrifice everything for her family. On the other hand, a sort of familial civil war ensues with Chang’s aunt Tam, the sister of Chang’s father, and her clear grudge against Chinh for the miseries her caused her family during the Land Reforms. It is a family drama plunges us deep in Vietnamese tradition and lets us discover many important aspects of Vietnam such as the importance of food (Seriously, I got hungry by the great description), the reverence of the ancestors, family bonds, and Thu Huong gives us such picturesque descriptions of her beloved country. Yet the novel exposes many hardships that especially women face in a masculine, and at times, very patriarchal society. The novel lets us as well ponder very important question. We ponder the deepness and importance of family bonds, the conservation of traditions, the gender roles in society, and personal freedom VS tradition. For how far are we willing to defend our family considering all their bad actions? Are we to accept previous traditions and customs forced upon us just to conserve them, even if they are toxic to our happiness? These and more are some of the main dilemmas that befall our young protagonist.

So again, I loved this novel and it not only let me learn more things of a place foreign to me, but it really invited me to reflect upon several matters such as family, blood relations, and heritage amongst other. Thu Huong allowed me hear some voices and experiences from Vietnam that go beyond the outsider portrayal. I highly recommend this novel.

This fictional account of growing up in Vietnam after the war is often promoted as the first novel from Vietnam ever published in the US, and one that was often banned in its own country. Indeed its author has spent time in jail and definitely expresses anti-communist views in this book, as well as the others in the trilogy.

But it is more than a critical look at the impact Communism had on the lives of ordinary people - people with small shops or a little land - property that was "reclaimed" by the new government and ostensibly redistributed for the good of all, but all too often only for the good of the higher ups in the Party. Huong does explore the reforms that were made several years following the war, and property that was returned.

Huong is a woman, and focuses on how these grand ideas created by men in offices are all too often born out by women in homes and on farms, in small businesses. Property is taken from women; a Party loyal brother insists his sister not marry the love of her life because his family has wealth - splitting up the couple even though she is already pregnant with his daughter (who becomes the protagonist). The resultant daughter (Hang) becomes a pawn - the Party loyalist Uncle wants to use her (literally) to promote his Communist ideals, as she becomes an export worker in Moscow. Her aunt (whose brother fathered Hang) loves her dearly and sacrifices greatly to ensure Hang is educated but wants her to continue the old ways, keeping all the traditions alive. Hang's own mother also has almost zero agency in her own life - losing the man she loves, losing a leg, losing her business, left to sell a few candies out of a window to try to feed herself and her daughter.

So there is much here - feminism, anti-communism, modernism vs tradition, power vs agency. Food.

Grace Paley wrote, "We have been hearing for many years from Americans who seemed to consider the Vietnamese experience -- life and war -- their own. At last a woman, a Vietnamese woman, tells us Vietnamese life: the village, the city, the repression and expansion, the middle peasant, the poor peasant, the years of exquisite food and no food, working in the Soviet Union -- and all beautifully told so that we can begin to understand not where we were for years, but where and how they -- the Vietnamese -- are now."

Paradise of the Blind is the first novel from Vietnam published in the United States, and banned in its own country. Its author, Dương Thu Hương, is a political dissident who has been imprisoned in her own country for her writing and outspoken criticism. I hadn't heard of this novel until the coordinator of the IB Diploma Program sent me a note about it after a coordinator meeting, letting me know that it was a popular choice for Works in Translation, a required component of IB Literature, which I teach. Next year our curriculum is changing and we need to replace three of the current works in translation, so I used this an opportunity to read this novel. I loved it, and I'm excited for the opportunity to teach it. The story is narrated by a young woman named Hang who has left Hanoi to work in the then Soviet Union; she receives a telegram letting her know that her uncle Chinh (who at that time is in Moscow) is very ill, and she must go to him. From there the novel shifts back to Vietnam to unfurl the story of Hang, her mother, and her Aunt Tam; the focus is really on these three women. Hang's mother, Que, is fiercely loyal to her brother Chinh despite his pettiness and greed. Hang's Aunt Tam hates Chinh for causing the death of her brother Ton, Hang's father and the one love of Que's life. Throughout the novel, the women are the ones who make the sacrifices, and the cost is everything.

I love stories that evoke a strong sense of place, and the descriptions of Hanoi are heavy: sensual, beautiful, oppressive. (The descriptions of Russia are also heavy: icy and oppressive.) Food is clearly central to the way people interact with each other, either with generosity or contempt, and I'll just go ahead and admit right now that this book made me hungry. The descriptions of food are among the best and most memorable I've ever read. (less)

I thought this was going to be really good. It was the first novel translated from Vietnamese to English even though it was only published in 1988. That says a huge amount about many things, most of it supposition.

The plot follows the life of Hang, a young woman, in a series of flashbacks and contemporary reflections. We follow her as she studies in Moscow and visiting her ageing uncle there.

As she grows, she discovers what has caused the tensions between her, her mother, her aunt and her uncle, and she fights to keep in play multiple loyalties.

Her childhood has been difficult with an absent father and a mother who has sacrificed everything for her. There’s a whole ton of emotional baggage buried beneath the surface, as you’d expect from Vietnam in the 1980s, but while I really wanted an insight into Vietnamese culture and particularly the political issues, I didn’t really get it in the form I was expecting.

I guess I was after docudrama and what I got was the story of one family from the point of view of a active critic of the Communist government.

The fact that Vietnam has banned the book for its political stance surprises me on the one hand because it doesn’t have outright criticism in its pages. But when you’ve lived all your life serving a Communist leadership, you learn, I suppose, to make your case with more subtlety.

This makes the criticism harder to spot in a novel that places what we’re having for dinner and a description of a moonlit night on the same par as what the local communist cadre is up to.

And maybe that’s the point, that the Party isn’t front and centre, that daily life is more important than political ideology. If so, the novel works a charm.

The storytelling is very fragmented and the characters aren’t developed too much. While this may be frustrating for western readers, it definitely romanticises the beauty of Vietnam and cultural essentials like its food and so, for Vietnamese, I can see how would strike a very melodic chord. (less)

Written in 1988, Paradise of the Blind was the first Vietnamese novel published in the United States (in 1993). Every time I read a translated novel, I’m amazed by the art that is translation — to translate not just the words, but the feelings, the unspoken gestures, and the atmosphere. This was a book where I felt the power of translation very acutely, because the writing had such a specific feel to it: it was so lyrical, melancholy, full of descriptions that I kept associating with a lush pastel palette. I wondered if these were the same feelings the original text would have evoked. Or perhaps what was added in this translation, or lost.

In Paradise of the Blind, Hang and her mother are caught in the ideological chasm that has torn the family apart: on one hand, Hang’s Uncle Chinh is completely devoted to the Communist party, and on the other, her Aunt Tam was denounced by the party and lost her family and her land. This book is an intimate portrait into the messy interplay between survival, materialism, and ideology. It got me thinking about how ideas of being dutiful to your family can slip into unhealthy relationships predicated on giving and giving.

This book is a close-up of just a few characters and included little historical context, but the dynamics between Hang, her mother, Uncle Chinh, and Aunt Tam, are deeply embedded in the bigger political forces in play in 1950s-80s Vietnam. The author, Duong Thu Huong, was expelled from the Communist party the year after she wrote this book and imprisoned briefly. Today, the book remains banned in Vietnam. I feel like there’s this Western fetishization of books that are banned in their home country, especially if the book is critical of communism, but I also have to admit that this book caught my eye because it is banned. But there are no sides to take in this book, no damning critique of a specific ideology or the other; instead, a quiet, and slightly existential, meditation. (less)

It is the early 1980s and 20-year-old Hang is a Vietnamese “exported worker” living in the Soviet Union. As she takes a train journey to Moscow, she reflects on her childhood and her mother’s stories from the time before she was born. In this coming-of-age story, the heroine navigates conflicting and sometimes destructive devotions to both blood lines and the Communist Party.

Paradise of the Blind is a lovely piece of literature, which was banned in Vietnam a year after it was published. I found the bright and loving Hang to be an inspiring character and I loved the ending of the novel. While Huong certainly offers criticism of the Communist Party and of some elements of patriarchy in Vietnamese culture, I appreciated that she did so in a nuanced way and that she also tells a wonderful story beyond just that. This book also provides an interesting glimpse into life in rural and urban Vietnam in the post-US war decades, and explores the bleak impact of some of the more repressive measures taken by the Communist Party in Vietnam.

Huong -- who volunteered on the fronts in Vietnam’s wars with the US and China -- was long disillusioned by the corruption and repression she saw in the Party. This book was published in 1988; in 1989 Huong was expelled from the Party and she also spent time in jail because of her writings. Most (all?) of her books have been banned in Vietnam and her later works have only been published outside her country. (less)

This book is an enlightening look at the way the rise of communism in Vietnam tore families apart and rooted trauma for generations to come. The story follows young Hang, who grew up after the war. Her father was exiled by her uncle, a communist official who returned to his hometown to bring about the new order. Hang's mother feels a responsibility for her brother, even when he tears the family apart. Hang's aunt, her father's sister, is vengeful and pours herself into building her wealth for the last of her family's blood: Hang.

This is a good story, but simple and with limited perspective. I'd recommend this simply because of its historical significance. Huong was, herself, a communist revolutionary and came to change her views when she saw the devastation it brought to families. She was eventually imprisoned for her writing, even after the country encouraged artists to share their true feelings again instead of streamlining them with the state agenda. That, in itself, is amazing.

On its own, it didn't make me feel terribly connected to the characters or their struggle, but a good read nonetheless. (less)

The characters in this novel are real and I can picture them living and breathing right here in Hanoi. Duong Thu Huong is a great writer writing about real Vietnamese people. Her book centers around a Vietnamese girl growing up and left ignorant of much of her own background. Her parents loved each other but in Communist Vietnam their love was dangerous.

Throughout the book Hang, the young girl, has to maneuver her way through the relationships she has with 3 distinct families: her mother, her mother’s brother Uncle Chinh; and her father’s sister, Aunt Tam. At times she rejects one or all of these 3 families, particularly as she starts college, but she gets pulled back to each, mainly out of obligation and rarely out of love.

I found it difficult to put the book down in a reading. It is not a “big” book in its scope but it is a big book in covering the social, moral and political woes of the country of Vietnam. The author has been jailed before for her other books. Her truth apparently is dangerous. (less)

Duong Thu Huong takes her reader through a harrowing story of the ways in which revolutionary totalitarianism and communism can tear families and even persons apart. She invites us into the story of Hang, a Vietnamese girl whose parents' marriage is ripped apart by the victory of the communist North Vietnamese. Hang finds herself torn between two competing loyalties: the loyalty of her mother to her brother as family, and the loyalty of her father's sister toward her as the last surviving member of the line.

In the midst of this, we catch a glimpse of the way the revolutionary ideals of the North Vietnamese became tyrannical and repressive, especially to those at the margins of society struggling to make a living: small farmers, street vendors, college students.

In the end, the only hope seems to be leaving behind Vietnam, allegorized as purple flowers growing over a morasse of decay, for other hopeful futures.

Sadly, Huong herself will likely never leave Vietnam, as she has been denied permission to travel despite her multiple awards. A difficult but worthy read. (less)

The story is rich in detail and free of cliche. It depicts the complexity of Vietnamese culture, the symbolic value of food, class distinctions, and conflicts between traditions and ideologies.

Hang’s relationships with other characters symbolises the writer's message. Her relationship with her mom symbolises her uneasiness & criticism with traditional confucian/asian values, while her relationship with her father symbolises her criticism towards communism and corruption. The protagonist led us in reflecting these as she feels conflicted throughout the story, unsure of what to do.

The book is full of metaphors and allegories that won’t stop our mind to wander & link them, equipped with rich characters with complex emotions and feelings. It also illustrates the rich Viatnamese culture with detailed mentions of foods & its culture.


The title represents how the characters were happily yet blindly following their traditions/patriarchal structures/communist ideologies, without realizing how much suffering they cause harm to oneself and others.

(less)

Growing up in Vietnam during the communist 70s and 80s, young Hang is used to hardships. Her cadre maternal uncle has her father's family classified as landlords (for owning a small paddy). Her father is sent away. Hang is raised alone, by her mother with her paternal aunt's help. Her paternal Aunt Tam can never forgive Hang's father for sending her brother away, most likely to his death. Tam can barely tolerate how Hang's mother continually helps her brother, despite the fact that he ruined her own family's lives. She feeds his kids when he is struggling, even though Hang then suffers lack of food. She sells the inheritance jewelry Tam gave for Hang. Her brother even says her work as a maker and vendor of vermicelli means she is not a real proper peasant.

Hang manages to get to college, but then needs to drop out to help her mother. In this novel we hear many stories of the typical Vietnamese and how they struggle through this time period of uncertainty. (less)

It is a bit of a pity, as there is so much potential in this story. With only 258 pages, this is a short book and the author would have had so much room to go into depth about how the protagonist's relationship with her mother, aunt and uncle evolves and which impact the political system has on the relationships between the individual characters. Instead, the actual plot appears to be secondary and I felt like I was following a character around that was just talking about the food that is being eaten and the ingredients used to prepare the individual dishes. While I primarily read this book because I wanted to learn something about Vietnam and food undeniably is an important and interesting part of every culture, I think the author should have written a separate book on Vietnamese cuisine and filled this one with a story. (less)

This book really magnetizes me despite a little confusion to catch up with the style of the author at first. I felt empathy and helplessness for the painful and lay lắt existence of the characters;though
in some period there is a ray of sun and laughing but at large the sadness and the constant feeling of despair pervade the whole story creeping into every corner of Hang's memory.
Que, Hang's mother, spend her energy and tỉme trying to bridge the gap with her young brother, but it is also this blood tie that blithely yawns the chasm with her only child. Aunt Tam is my favorite character with a strong and forceful disposition that can dwindle anyone before her and it is the longing for revenge that sustains her after the other members of her family were indirectly killed by Hang's uncle.
The ending is the brightest part after the whole bleak recollection of Hang. (less)

What is it like to be binded by the past while dreaming and reaching for a better future? What is it like to be suffocated by society's beliefs and conventions, doubting whether if there is any meaning left at all in holding onto those things that have gradually been decaying for so long, and yet cannot be so heartless as to reject them entirely. Paradise is where? In the past, in the future, or in somewhere that cannot be fully understood and recognized? The cruelty and hopefulness of life, the cruelty and holiness of human relations and affections. We are a despicable and resilient creature as we all try to navigate and find meanings in this mists of grayness that is called history and humanity.

Very heavy and haunting book, probably one of the best of modern Viet literature that I've read so far. It's a great shame that this book is banned in Vietnam. (less)

this isn't an in-depth review, but this is a wonderfully written novel that essentially denounces the atrocities of the Vietnamese government as Communism begins to take influence. it follows Hang and her life in Vietnam growing up as she witnesses a plethora of events unfold including the brutal effects the Communist regime have on people. Huong is such a talented writer as every sentence in this book is structured in vivid prose, and the story is delicate yet strong. the ending was satisfying, and the symbolism is strong. i wanted to include a quote from the book that, in my opinion, well conveys the overall plot and strengths of the book.
- "I can't squander my life tending these faded flowers, these shadows, the legacy of past crimes."
critical rating: 5/5
personal rating: 4.5/5 (i really enjoyed it!) (less)

Duong Thu Huong is a disappointed idealist and her novel can be considered a criticism of the socialist experiment with its hollow ideological principles filled with corrupt practices and tawdry materialist goods. The novel illustrates how institutions and policy betray their ideals and cripple the human spirit. There is a minor soapbox speech to that effect in the latter part of the novel but the disillusionment is illustrated throughout the text in the form of reminiscences of Hang's childhood in Vietnam. Her memories are recalled during a bleak train journey from a Russian factory town, where she is employed as an itinerant worker, to Moscow where she has been summoned by her uncle.

The young woman's recollections depict the life draining struggle to survive in a worker’s paradise filled with neglect and decay against a background of the vivid natural beauty of the countryside and descriptions involving the preparation of various dishes and their resulting tastes and aromas. Although I’ve yet to read Babette’s Feast by Isak Dinesen, I would imagine that Huong’s novel shares some similarities.

The internal drama focuses of how she tries to navigate within the turmoil amongst her immediate family whose behaviors are a consequence of the collision between socialist ideology and a conservative family-oriented agrarian culture. Their irrational responses are motivated by duty, revenge, and humiliation. (less)

Offering a study of Vietnamese women across the 1960s-1980s, Duong's novel moves easily from Saigon to Moscow, tracking the pull of ideology that more and more underscores Vietnamese action at the expense of family ties. Duong situates this within three women's lives, and the uncle/brother who binds them to one another as he invests in strict communistic ideology.

It's a powerful story, though it pulls some of the nationalist punches that Duong later explored in her Novel Without a Name. Still, that one, concerned with loss of innocence in the face of bureaucratic excess, covered men far more, and so this glimpse into women in these conditions is valuable culturally and aesthetically, as the translation captures ease with metaphor and symbolism. (less)

This book portrays the sorrows and disillusionment the average Vietnamese face under the various political reformation events in Vietnam around the 1950s-1980s, through the eyes of the protagonist, Hang. Hang was forced to cut short her education to become an "exported worker" in what was then the Soviet Union. We get to understand Hang's past through her flashback, detailing how the various political reform ripped her family and village apart.

This was a book that I really took my time reading. The tone was melancholy as it portrays humans' despair and suffering. It felt that life was truly unfair, as we went on the journey to Hang's past. We get to see how Hang's character build-up throughout her flashbacks, how she develops her own characteristics and sets her own values. It's one book that really got me to ponder a lot. (less)

Most of the story happens while Hang is on a train, traveling to see her uncle in Moscow. The book cuts between her journey, and moments/memories of her childhood, growing up poor in a tiny village in Vietnam.

Since the timeline isn’t completely linear, and there are gaps (it’s often difficult to determine how much time has passed), I sometimes found it difficult to follow. Also, the book was slow-moving at first, but the characters became more interesting as it went along. I found myself quite invested in Hang, her mother, her aunt, and her uncle, wondering what was going to happen to each of them.

Overall, 3 stars. It was mostly interesting, but not terribly riveting or moving. (less)

Until I was about 75% finished, I was settled firmly on 3-star rating. I felt the book was slow and verbose and less nuanced than I expected for one exploring the political and relational issues at hand. I was fully aware that I may have been missing elements because of the cultural divide.

The last quarter of the book really picks up in terms of empathy and cohesion. The descriptive detail does not lessen, but there are some poignant metaphors and epiphany moments that create a very satisfying conclusion to the rest of the book. As Americans, our knowledge of Vietnam after the early 1970s is sorely lacking. I appreciate this look inside and feel richer for having explored it. (less)

"Paradise of the Blind" is set in Vietnam and written by a Vietnamese author whose works were banned in her own country and who lived under house arrest for quite some time (I believe I read that she is now living outside of Vietnam). Through reminiscing, it tells the story of a young girl and her family who live through the expulsion of the French and eventually of the Americans. Life is not easy for this family, even though the girl's uncle is a communist party official.

It is a rare look into life in North Vietnam (rare for me, anyway), and that alone makes it interesting. The flow seemed a bit disjointed and that made the story difficult to follow at times. I'm still glad I read it. (less)

This was actually a really beautiful story about a daughter and her complicated relationship with her mother and aunt, struggling with socio-economic related problems that are the root of the strained relationships she has with her mother and aunt, as well as the root of her mother's issues with her aunt. This story is a lightly veiled memoir about the author, and her desire to please her mother, succeed in life, and not abandon her family, no matter how shitty her uncle is. It is raw and human and really melancholy, but a fascinating different perspective of a different generation and culture in a different country. (less)

Through Hang's flashbacks, the author offers a political commentary and a wonderful exploration of complex familial relationships and personal development. The imagery is striking and often mouth-watering (sooooo many food descriptions, which was significant in terms of celebrating an important aspect of Vietnamese culture and family life).

It is a beautiful and an extremely important book and while I would definitely recommend it, it was a slow read. Even though the imagery was lovely, I did find some of the exceptionally long descriptions a bit tedious.
3.5 (less)

A good insight for Western readers into life in Vietnam post-war. Although I know what period it refers to, it was almost timeless and could have been written about life 50 or 100 years ago, with the focus on family struggles, the downtrodden life of women, food and festivals, and the absence of modern technology. I would have liked more about how our heroine Hang came to be working in a Russian textile factory.

Even though Paradise of the Blind was an assigned reading, I would read this novel for fun. I have never seen such collective mastery, elegance, and poise in an author’s writing. Duong Thu Huong’s exceptional grace with rhetoric works to craft a powerful story of Vietnam during the Lao Dong communist regime through the lenses of a fragmented family. At the same time, Huong provides an extraordinary detailed insight into the bonds tying traditional Vietnamese culture. Wonderful read. 5/5

Although I really enjoyed the Vietnamese culture and the sort of more first-hand account of Communism and how it affected everyday people in Vietnam, I got confused by the roundabout chronology of events. I liked this bildungsroman and thought it was well written, but because of the nature of Hang's different stages of life being presented and not really knowing where we are in time at any given moment, that's what ultimately brought it down a star for me. Really great novel. (less)

I appreciated the subtlety of the political aspects of this book. I felt that Thuong did a great job of infusing controversial topics into a realistic plot line whose characters were never good or bad, simply flawed. This is a great book for introducing global concerns whose effects are still felt today.

This book started well, and I looked forward to reading it up until the halfway point. Then it dragged on with some unsuccessful injection of a boring romance. The description on life in Vietnam and the of folly of communism were very interesting. However the story on the protagonist was not. The ending was alright, so all-in all a pretty good read.

Story wise it was a strong perspective into a post war Vietnamese world. The timeline was very confusing as it jumped constantly without giving you any clues. The story had a lot of emotions and characters, but not a lot really happens in the story. It won't be for everyone but I definitely liked it. (less)

A few things:

I love this book. While visiting Cambodia and Thailand we become more determined to eventually visit Vietnam. It’s a beautiful part of the world and the people are warm and kind to visitors. This book is about the burden of family expectations, the joy of having someone believe in you, the impact of social unrest on those struggling to survive and so much more. I highly recommend it.

Read this for our book club and like it. A book that depicts vividly life in post-land transformation (cai cach ruong dat) in Vietnam. I don't really like how the author builds the villains. They are just straight-up cruel and despicable from the beginning to the end, without any nuances. If you can, read the book in its original language. A lot has been lost in translation. (less)

I give this 3.5 stars. It was a detailed portrait of life in Vietnam and communism and changing times. However there was almost no voice or character to the narrator. Hang does not have any thoughts of her own, she is simply relaying events which made it more difficult to get into this book.

The story of 3 Vietnamese women struggling to live with dignity in a dystopian Communist country. The title of the novel is ironic as, while there is plenty of blindness (both literal and metaphorical), paradise is nowhere to be found. A very sad story with a hopeful ending.

some background knowledge or on-the-spot research of the region's history and politics is required to fully appreciate the story that unfolds itself in front of our very eyes. That aside, it'a a captivating read for those who are into the turbulent times of the Vietnamese history. (less)

While the main message of the author comes through loudly and clearly, I’m guessing something is lost through translation with regards the story element.

Characterisation was well done. I especially enjoyed sights, sounds, smells, locations of Vietnam throughout.

The subtle flow of this book is so beautiful. It was a glimpse into a world not familiar to me and yet the roots underneath can resonate with everyone. Loved the choppiness of the book when usually things like that annoy me... a nod towards her skill in story telling.

Found this well-written, and it had a nice ending. However, it was overall a boring book.

I’d recommend it to someone who wanted to understand 1980s Vietnamese culture and politics a bit more, but only if that person had exhausted some other, better offerings.

[Around the World in 195 books challenge: Vietnam]. A beautifully written saga about how Vietnamese politics tore a family apart, and how it impacted the life of the narrator who was caught in the middle.

I adored this book. I felt completely transported to both the period and atmosphere in which this was set. The fact that Duong Thu Huong had her books banned and was not permitted to leave Vietnam add to the rawness and bravery it took to reveal her truth.

This was an interesting book that focused a lot on the traditions and customs of the Vietnamese people, and was quite fascinating. There was a vague thread throughout, of women’s responsibilities to their ancestors and male relatives, even to the detriment of their own life.

A gripping and heartbreaking masterpiece. A brutal story of poverty, self-sacrifice, and ingratitude.

Also, this book has some of the best descriptions of food I've ever encountered in a novel. (less)
just re-read. Beautiful writing.

Great book with a clean style

Duong Thu Huong’s Paradise of the Blind covers the impact of the Communist regime on a family with an effective portrayal of family strife that doesn’t get didactic. Hang is the central character, a North Vietnamese woman we see initially as an “exported worker” in the Soviet Union living in a Spartan dormitory. She receives a communication from an uncle in Moscow, a party official, which leads to her decision to take a rail cross-country to visit him.

The novel alternates between that trip and the sundering of her family. Hang’s story has three centers of gravity; her almost inhumanly self-sacrificing mother, Que; her full-of-himself maternal uncle, Chinh; and her paternal aunt, Tam. Her family being torn asunder by those centers began when her maternal uncle, a soldier who had returned from the war and became a local political leader, turned on her father on the grounds that the latter came from a landlord family and forced her mother to denounce him. The uncle is in charge of local political discipline during a disastrous period of land reform after the end of what the Vietnamese called the American War. When policies are changed and the uncle is disgraced, the village’s enmity focuses on the mother.

Chinh’s nature is revealed early on when he complains to his sister about her meeting with Tam, her sister-in-law. Although ostensibly an issue of political rectitude, he then complains about the impact it could have on his career. He does this a few times. Han’s reaction to that is to blame herself for not raising him right (she was the elder sibling); nothing that Chinh does shakes that loyalty. When he falls on harder times, she devotes herself to his children even above Hang, which causes one of the main conflicts of the plot. Part of that choice is because of her issue with Hang’s relationship with Tam.

The embitterment of Tam against Chinh (and to some extent Que) because of what he did to her brother is balanced out by an attempt to claim the loyalty of Hang. Tam, despite having been deprived of everything as a class enemy, was able to work her way back up to a measure of prosperity and takes Hang under her wing, supporting her financially and exhorting her to make the most of herself. Since Tam is childless and Hang her only sibling’s only child, Tam regards Hang as her family’s last gasp.

The characterizations are vivid and well-drawn. Although Que’s self-sacrifice could have seemed unreal in the hands of a less skilled author, the portrayal of the mix of wanting to hold on to her remaining family and her resentment of the influence on Tam makes her tendency to accord a higher priority to Chinh’s children not unrealistic. Tam’s story shows her indomitable will and one almost gets the sense that her anger at what had been done her family had much to do with keeping her going.

Even the minor characters are well-drawn. For example, the portraits of the people promoted as political commissars in the village who were no-accounts prior to their promotion have back stories that are rich and engaging.
(less)

Very evocative Vietnamese novel about a young woman and her relationship with her mother and aunt. Woven in are past of old wrongs enacted during the revolution, the dodgy Communist party uncle, working as labour in a Russian labour, the superstitions and dramas of village life and the need to move on. Revenge and forgiveness are themes here but there are no easy answers or dramatic reconciliations. Vietnamese food & ritual is depicted in loving detail.

The amount that I loved this book was amazing to me. I mean, it was summer reading. I have to write an essay on it and everything. I practically HAVE to hate it. But I didn't.

Huong's writing is so rich and descriptive that you are literally transported to the Vietnamese villages she speaks of, to the old train rattling through the cold Russian landscape, to the empty Communist cities, and to the busy, crowded streets of Hanoi. I have never read a book so rich in cultural description before, which perhaps shows that I lack as a reader, but also shows how utterly amazing the writing is in this book. It is obvious that Huong loves her country, and mourns for what has been lost during the Communist regime. Yet she still celebrates the rich culture of Vietnam, particularly through her reverent descriptions of the food. While I was reading this book, I was constantly craving Pho, because she kept talking about it, describing the smell, the voice of the vendor, the taste of the broth. The food was as much a part of the story as the people themselves.

One of my friends was complaining about how there isn't any real story in this book. And yeah, I have to admit, it isn't the most exciting thing I've ever read. It's about life. A girl's life, written in memories as she rides on a train to visit her sick uncle. She is in a country where she feels utterly alienated. Her memories are dripping with nostalgia. OF COURSE it isn't nonstop action. The fact that it isn't makes you--or at least it made me--appreciate the descriptions and the characters more.

And the story definitely had its share of pain, sorrow, horror and heartbreak. It's about a Communism and starving people. What do you expect? But it also had its share of hope, triumph, love and joy. I thought it was balanced enough. Like I said before, it was very human. Which was good.

So yeah. Should have hated it. Loved it. Will now face the stigma of my classmates for actually liking a book we HAVE to read. But it's definitely worth it. (less)

In this beautiful, lyrical, and haunting novel about family relationships and what it means to be "home", Huong raises the question, is blood really thicker than water? While the author does engage some of the political issues plaguing a post-war Vietnam trying to redefine itself, she does not preach but rather tells the story of gifted, tragic, sad, and alienated individuals. I did not expect this to be a page-turner, but Huong swept me off my feet with her gorgeously poetic descriptions of setting--from the small enchanting Vietnamese village of Hang's Aunt Tam to her mother's hut in the slums of Hanoi, to Moscow in the dead of winter. This book was like my very own magical carpet--lush, concrete, sensual, heartbreaking--and just the kind of escape I was craving. I couldn't put it down. The translation by Phan Huy Duong and Nina McPherson was exquisite. Here's an example:

"On my first winter day in Russia, I had stayed awake for six hours, just to watch my first snowfall. It was freezing, but I stayed glued to the window, watching these strange flowers flood the earth with their icy whiteness. Light sparked off them in blinding shards, frail and luminous as a childhood dream. This beauty pierced my soul like sadness. Extremes have always wounded me...The snow fell to an unfamiliar, foreign earth. Beauty knows no frontiers, seduces without discrimination. The snow spilled onto the earth as if the sky had welled over with flowers" (Huong, 82-83).

This reminded me (a native New Orleanian) of the first snowfall I witnessed at the age of 21 in St. Louis, Missouri one night. Huong captures perfectly that feeling of enchantment and wonder I experienced. Beautiful book!

(less)

This book, written by a Vietnamese Woman and translated to English by Phan Huy Duong and Nina McPerson, is set in Vietnam and Russia after the Vietnam War with the U.S. and tells the story of Hang, her mother and her paternal aunt and through them tells the story of Vietnam after the war and the emergence of communism. This story starts in Russia where Hang is working as an exported worker in a textile plant and is told in a series of flashbacks in Hangs life. We see Hang as a young girl with her single parent mother wondering about her father. She meets her paternal aunt. Later she meets her maternal uncle and his family. Hang's mother is at first devoted to her daughter but then becomes devoted to her brother's children and spends all she has in her life for them. At the same time, the paternal aunt devotes all her life to becoming rich and pursuing her hatred of Hang's uncle. If it wasn't for this paternal aunt, Hang would have nothing. I really liked the writing (or translated) writing. It was easy to read, yet very descriptive of the land and culture. I liked learning about Vietnam through this women's writing. She wrote under communism. She was also an active member of the communist party but wrote under a libereration of the writer. A freedom to write about the country rather than political claptrap. Later it was banned in Vietnam. I have read other books about communism and books of communism in Asian culture and I just don't get it. It seems so obsurd. I can only think that things must have been so bad to allow people to make such crazy political decisions that seem so harmful. I would recommend this book to anyone interested in reading women authors of different languages and cultures. (less)

The history of the politics and struggle of the North Vietnamese people and the Communist rule was interesting, many of us in our group were not familiar with these struggles and the relationships between these two groups. We also didn't realize that Vietnamese people were recruited to work in factories in Russia.
Many of us thought the relationship between Hang and her mother Que was sad. The closeness hampered by Que's brother and his family and their needs.
To quote the introduction of the book - To follow Hang's memory is to be immersed in both the beauty and cruelty of rural Vietnamese culture. It is to feel, as Hang does, both the strength and the suffering of Vietnamese women in the face of the crushing weight of the Confucian cult of male authority, a legacy of more than one thousand years of Chinese rule. As a Vietnames woman she must confront a deeply Confucian culture of ancestor worship: where peasants still pray to altars...;where the young submit to the old; where children yield to the authority of their parents, sisters to their brothers, and wives to their husbands.

MINI BOOK REVIEW

[Paradise of the Blind]
A Vietnamese girl comes of age in 1980 amidst Communist forces and traditional villages. I loved the contrast between her aunt, mother, and uncle. Each member of the family held distinct motivations and interacted/depicted the government according to their beliefs. Hang must find her way between these pressures. Paradise of the Blind is written as a series of reflections on a train ride that build up to a familial meeting. While I enjoyed the anticipation this strategy gave, the realities of life seemed blurred. I wanted more gritty detail in her reflections. I also wanted more everyday humor and opportunities to get to know Hang in her own right. ⚡️4/5 (less)

I read this book as part of my research on Vietnam and found it painted a desolate picture of life under the fledgling communist government in the early days after the French lost the country in 1954, and after the American War. Having said that, the detail of ordinary lives is fascinating: the food, the proverbs, the homes, the clothes, the beautiful countryside. The descriptions of food bring home how hard it was for people to survive, and how shocking the deprivation they faced. She builds a picture of a resilient people who during the 20th Century faced a series of wars that tore their country apart. The main character’s self-sacrificing mother is a street vendor, Hang is a student, and their lives are driven by the pursuit of survival against almost impossible odds. You can only admire their spirit and at the same time realise how spoilt we in the west have become. To suffer as they have and rebuild as they are doing now is an amazing testament to the Vietnamese people. As research it was terrifically useful, especially the chapters that deal with the terrifying land reform campaigns 1953-1956, but for me it didn’t enthral as a novel. Although it is beautifully written and very strong on atmosphere it does read rather like a memoir. (less)

Although it was hard to get into Duong's story telling style at first, Paradise of the Blind is a beautifully written tale of a young woman trying to make sense of the world around her. The commentary throughout the story on the affect of communism in Vietnam is powerful, and provokes thought. On a lighter note, the reverence for food in Vietnamese culture is very obvious and can easily make one hungry while reading this.
Having some knowledge of Vietnamese culture and customs is really helpful for understanding certain things- especially family dynamic. The relationship between Que and Uncle Chinh's family won't make as much sense through a western lens as through a Vietnamese one.

Paradise of the Blind is a good read, even if you only look at it lightly and don't read in to Duong's style. The imagery is powerful, and the interesting time line can throw you for a loop if you don't pay enough attention. I reread this book and was able to pick up on so much more the second time around. This is definitely one of those books where no matter how much you read it, you can always get something more from it. (less)

Although I haven't rated this book very highly, it was an amazing book to read. The sad tale of young Hang and her mother and aunt as they struggle to survive various political and social reforms is tragic and exhausting. It's a book that looks critically at some Vietnamese traditions, and shows what it was like for poor people to try to get ahead in the 80's. The author was the leader of a communist youth brigade, a soldier when China attacked Vietnam, and a member of the communist party who became disillusioned and expelled from the party, and then imprisoned. Before going to Vietnam a bit over a year ago, I read a wide variety of books that prepared me a little bit for the complexity of Vietnam. I wish I'd read this one, too, although if I had, I probably wouldn't have wanted to go at all. The glossary of Vietnamese food provided by the translators was a helpful addition, and I wish I were back in Hanoi to look for some of the dishes. I would recommend this book to anyone planning a trip to Vietnam. (less)

Story of two families connected by marriage but separated by status in Vietnam’s communist system after the American war, with some history dating back to the French war. It’s told by the daughter/niece of the conflicted families, now working in Russia as an “exported worker,” who depicts the cultural and personal changes and losses under the regime, which has failed to bring material benefits, social justice, or corruption-free rule despite its military and political victories. First published in Vietnam in 1988 during an interlude of open expression, it was then banned (and the author expelled from the Communist Party, after 20-plus years of military service and party membership) for its condemnation of the failure of the system at the expense of the weak (which reminded me a bit of Steinbeck). A compact work and exceptional, often poetic, on the sensory details of country and city settings and day-to-day family, social, and cultural life and traditions, which (as in Thailand) often have food customs at their center (a glossary is devoted mostly to food terms). 'Paradise of the Blind' is the riveting tale of a Vietnam torn apart by the communistic regimes of society. Set in the 1980s, the novel follows the life of a disciplined and resilient young woman named Hang who works in a Soviet Union textile factory to support her declining mother. The story is narrated through Hang's memories as she recalls her experiences growing up in the slums of Hanoi. Duong Thu Huong writes about the struggles of three, ineluctably related women: Hang who longs to know more about her father; her selfless mother who wants nothing more than to please her abusive brother; and the mysterious Aunt Tam who fights for her niece's better future. With its breathtaking descriptions of Vietnamese culture, this is the tale of three women fighting for their identities in an oppressive society. Despite its initial tendencies for uneventfulness, 'Paradise of the Blind' quickly begins to spark interest in its readers by providing a unique insight in to a previously unseen Vietnam. With an emotional story and powerful message, this book is a delight to behold. (less)

I knocked this book down a star because I've practically forgotten it since I read it four months ago. It's about a young Vietnamese woman whose family was torn apart by the war between communism and culture, and who goes to work in the Soviet Union as an "exported worker" in a factory. It has all the elements of things I would like to read about--good writing, strong and awesome female characters, childhood memories told in a believable way, long descriptions of yummy Vietnamese food--but I think somehow it failed to engage me as much as I wanted at the time I was reading it. I still would recommend it and will probably try some other book by this author before giving up on her and her amazing story (as a former communist & the first woman combatant present on the front lines turned dissenter and political prisoner in Vietnam). And I agree with everyone who says it's about time we had a story about the Vietnam War that's written by and about Vietnamese people--really.

Huong's heart wrenching story surprised me at first. From the description on Amazon, I was expecting a very mild tale, appealing mostly to women. Also, I also didn't realize the land reform had such a negative impact on the lives of the Vietnamese. Sometimes the translation was worded oddly but the way the translator interpreted the mood of each side story seemed perfect. Overall, Paradise of the Blind turned out to be far more thrilling than I had been expecting. All the horrific actions done to those opposed to the government's policies were gripping and kept my interest in the book. Casey suggested I read this book which she was required to read for this coming school year. It was a very interesting glimpse of life in Vietnam. It tells the story of three women: Hang, her mother and her aunt. Hang's mother's life is changed forever when her brother, a member of the government, enforces the new law stripping land from landowners and giving it to those who have no land. The ensuing shaming that is done forces Her father to run away. He ends up taking his own life. So, Hang and her mother are left to fend for themselves. Hang's aunt becomes her benefactor which causes her mother to withdraw her love and affection from Hang.

The point, I think, of the title is when you choose to be blind to what is really happening around you, there is a simple happiness whose root is ignorance. Do you choose ignorant, simple, surface-level understanding? Or, do you choose a deeper level of knowledge which leads to complicated happiness? Hang chooses the latter. (less)

Hang is a young Vietnamese woman working as an "exported garment maker" in Russia, trying to make money to send back to her family. As we hear of her modern day travails, coping with the cold winters and the cold attitudes of the Russian urban landscape, we also hear her history. Her mother was left to bring Hang up alone, after her father who came from a family of landowners was forced to leave. Her wealthy Aunt Tam tries to persuade Hang to get an education and better herself, but her ties to her family keep getting in the way.

It's an emotional and shocking book, and I can't quite believe how recent the history is. As far as I can tell, it's still banned in Vietnam, due to the political views the author portrays. Which is strange - there's no real criticism of communism as a dogma, but more the human story of power, corruption, and false hope.

It's a very simple telling of what is, in fact, quite a masterful novel. Enjoyable and thought provoking on many levels. (less)

This was an amazing read and my first novel taking place in Vietnam after the war. The translation was done well and fairly reflected the intricacies of the writer's original words.

The story is beautiful; Hang is a wonderful character that has to surmount troubles, both her own and those of others, to get to the point of self actualization that I think she gets to in the end. Một cuốn sách gây sốc. Thời đó và bây giờ cũng vậy. Nguyên Hồng, còn quá trẻ mà cái nhìn lại quá già. (less)

Cho đến khi biết được tác phẩm này được viết khi tác giả tầm độ 17, 18 tuổi mình đã há hốc mồm.
Tầm cái tuổi khi mà mình vẫn đang loay hoay với bài vở, ăn, học thì Nguyên Hồng đã viết được một tác phẩm mang tính hiện thực xã hội gây ảnh hưởng sâu sắc, về xã hội hạ lưu và những mảnh đời bất hạnh.
Đọc Bỉ Vỏ mình cảm giác như đang đi phượt mà chẳng có kế hoạch, chẳng biết phía trước mình sẽ gặp ai, đi đâu, ăn gì, khám phá được gì mới mẻ, cứ thế mà đi, như là một chuyến hành trình của cảm xúc.
Lúc thì lo lắng đến nghẹt thở, khi thì vừa buồn cười vừa ấm áp vì những câu nói của anh Năm dành cho Bính, khi thì ấm ức, tức giận vì hành động tàn nhẫn của các nhân vật trong truyện. Mà mình nói đùa với bạn là như xem phim hành động giật gân Mĩ vậy.
Đọc xong gần 300 trang sách mình thấy nhẹ nhõm khi vừa dứt xong cái hành trình cảm xúc bấp bênh ấy, nhưng cảm xúc mạnh mẽ hơn là ngậm ngùi chua xót cho số phận của những nhân vật trong truyện, đặc biệt là phụ nữ và trẻ em :( Ai cho họ lương thiện khi mà xã hội cổ tục lạc hậu, bất công tàn khốc đã đẩy họ vào vòng vây lưu manh.
Văn học của Việt Nam mình cũng "không phải dạng vừa". (less)

Tối hơn cả "Tắt đèn" nữa, cảm giác như bản mở rộng của cuộc đời chị Dậu sau khi chạy vào màn đêm :(
Đoạn Bính từ người lương thiện trở thành bỉ vỏ (người đàn bà ăn cắp) chuyên nghiệp nhanh hơn siêu nhân biến hình. Rốt cuộc vẫn không nên uống rượu các bạn ạ, tránh cho cuộc đời thêm vài pha bẻ lái siêu quần. Càm ràm chút thôi chứ mình vẫn phục nhà văn Nguyên Hồng sát đất, U20 đã viết được thế này. Kiểu này phải tìm đọc "Những ngày thơ ấu", hơn cả nội dung tác phẩm, mình tò mò với việc tác giả đã trải qua những gì để có tư liệu viết "Bỉ vỏ" hơn. (less)

Tám Bính thật chả sướng hơn Chị Dậu là bao. Thiết nghĩ còn khổ hơn cà ngàn lần. Không danh phận, không con cái . Có mỗi mụn con về sau cũng chết mất . Đọc đến cuối tưởng khá hơn, tưởng rằng “vợ chồng” hối cải ngờ đÂu là bi kịch.
Tác phẩm nhuần nhuyễn mạch lạc như thế hoá ra đc viết bởi anh chàng chưa 18 . 1 kho tàng toàn từ địa phương đôi khi thấy hơi hoang mang . Nhưng riết rồi cũng quen. Thực sự hâm mộ Nguyên Hồng dã man . Mê từ hồi cấp 2 cơ .
Cuốn này tớ cũng đọc từ cấp 2 . Nhưng hồi đó chưa có hiểu hết toàn bộ. Hôm qua đọc đến hnay thì oo sao tâm trạng khó tả đến lạ . Thương cho Bính . 1 người đàn bà như bao người khác . Nếu bính sinh ra thời này có phải đỡ khổ hơn không ? Bây h tớ đang nghĩ khéo mình single mum cho đỡ 1 cục nợ 🙄. Ước mơ duy nhất là có những đứa trẻ của mình mạnh khoẻ hạnh phúc hehiho
